line: Comedy club]

Pete's luncheonette. Jerry and George are sitting at a 
              table.]
Are you through? [kind of irritated]

[pretends he's talking into a microphone] Uh, no, not at

Can you relax, it's a cup of coffee, Claire is a professional

Yeah.

[whistles disapproving] Ho ho ho, "Had to"? "Had

              "Had to" and "Maybe"?
Yeah!

Yes!

[to Claire] Now, a woman calls me, all right? She says

and, and maybe [again some gestures] she'll see me when

[takes off his glasses and rubs his eyes; panics] Right,

I've seen MOST of it. I guess my favorite would have to 
              be, uh...
I don't know... maybe.

I have. Funny, funny. In fact it was on TV just the other 
              night.
Well, we've made our decision. We want "The Kramer."

Jerry's apartment, night. Jerry and George are watching 
              a baseball

Five-thousand? Why would anybody buy Kramer for $5000? 
              (laughs)
Boy, the Yankees cannot buy a hit tonight!
So is it all over between you and... Marsha Mason?

Yeah. (picks up Nina's painting George bought) And by the 
              way, can

Tell you what, I'll make a deal with you. I'll sell it 
              to you right

Uh, there's seems to be a lot of trouble in the area just 
              behind the

Behind the dugout, that's where we were sitting the other 
              day.

Well, we're not going to show it, we don't want to encourage 
              that kind

the Armstrong's dining room. Mr. and Mrs. Armstrong are 
              having

...then, when I was seventeen, I ran away from home and 
              hopped a
More potatoes?
Yeah, sure. Please.
Yes, yes. Go on. You hopped a steamship to Sweden?
Yeah. (beat) And, it was a big one.

        Transcribed by
line: Brian Dickson

So, I fly a lot. I like planes. I was on a plane 
        the other day and I was wondering - are there keys to the plane? Do they 
        need keys to start the plane? Maybe that's what those delays on the ground 
        are sometimes. When you're just sitting there at the gate, maybe the pilot's 
        just up there in the cockpit going <mimics looking for keys> "Oh, 
        I don't believe this. Oh my god...I did it again." They tell you 
        it's something mechanical, because they don't want to come on the PA system..."Ladies 
        and gentlemen, we're going to be delayed here on the ground for a little 
        while, I uh...Oh God, this is so embarrassing...I - I left the keys to 
        the plane in my apartment." You see the technicians all running underneath 
        the plane; you think they're servicing it, but they're actually looking 
        for the magnet "hide-a-key" under the wing..."maybe he 
        left it up there somewhere..."

Jerry's apartment in the middle of the night. Jerry 
        comes out of his room. We hear his thoughts.

What is it about sleep that makes you so thirsty? Do dreams 
        require liquid? It's not like I'm running a marathon, I'm just lying there.
What the hell...? Why is the door open?
Kramer, what are you doing here!?

Jerry, now calm down, it's okay. I'm sorry. I didn't want to 
        wake you up! Y'know, I was watching "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo," 
        and I - y'know, I wanted to get some popcorn, and I, uh...I used the spare 
        keys that you gave me to come into your apartment to get your popper.
You scared me!
It's just me.
That's enough!

Forgot the popper... <goes to the kitchen, grabs the popper, 
        drops the lid, juggles it around, then exits.>
C'mon...c'mon...
Kramer! What are you doing?!
What does it look like I'm doing? What?
Get out! Get out of the bathroom, I gotta go!
Alright, alright...
C'mon!
Sorry.
Move it! Move it! Get going!

My drain's all clogged up! <Comes out of the bathroom in a 
        towel, covered in soap suds.>
Is that my towel?
I'm really happy the movie was sold out.

Hey, did you ever pretend there's like, murderers chasing you, 
        and you try and see how fast you can get your keys out and get into your 
        apartment?
I'm from Witchita, so...
Oh. I see. There he is! <Pretends the murderers are coming.>
Hurry, Jerry! He's coming! Hurry!
The murderers! <Jerry unlocks his door and they both run inside.>
That was close!
Did you see the look on that guy's face?

You were so fast with those keys. <They prepare 
        to kiss, but are interrupted by Kramer and his girlfriend coming out of 
        Jerry's bedroom, laughing and horsing around.>
Kramer! What the hell are you doing here?!
Hey, Jerry! How are ya? I thought you were going to the movies.
All right, that's it. Hand 'em over.
What?

What, you know what, the keys. I want the keys. You've lost your 
        key privileges.
Oh, come on!
No, come on!
What, what, I thought you went to the movies!
It was sold out!
Now how was I supposed to know it was going to be sold out?
That's the point.
What point?
Just, look, just give the keys.
Just give me another chance!
Don't ask me!
I'm asking you!
I'm telling you.
You're joking.
I'm serious!
It's not going to happen again!
Yes it will, now give me those keys!

O.K., fine, go ahead, you take the keys! But you're 
        going to regret this. <He angrily storms out. Kramer then re-enters 
        seconds later when he realizes he's left his girlfriend in Jerry's apartment.>
So put 'em in a safe place.
I will.
Where?
I don't know. I'll hide 'em. So, is Kramer upset?
I think so. I mean, he's acting really weird lately...he's different.
Well, maybe you should just give him the keys back.
I can't.
Is that Kramer? <Jerry nods.>
Who's there?

Uh, Kramer. <Jerry opens the door, Kramer enters. 
        Elaine waves at Kramer with the keys in her hand.> Oh, hi...uh...you 
        got the...
Oh, I'm not, uh...

No, no, no, it's o.k. I don't care about the keys. It's my fault. 
        I gave the keys away with my stupidity. I broke "the covenant of 
        the keys."
Jerry, give him the keys back.
Elaine...

I don't want the keys back! No, I'm glad the way things turned 
        out. I was clingin' to those keys, man! Like a branch on the banks of 
        a raging river. And now I have let go. And I'm free...to go with the current. 
        To float. (To Jerry) And I thank you.
Take the keys.

I don't want the keys! <Jerry tries to force the keys on Kramer, 
        but Kramer refuses.>
O.K.!
Now, one more thing - I would like my keys back.
Your spare set?
That's right.
You want 'em back?
Yeah. Yeah, I think it would be for the best.
Gee, Kramer, I uh...I don't know what to say.
Say yes! Yes, George. Yes!

Should I give you my keys, is that the transaction, trading keys...? 
        Because Elaine has my keys.
Well, you can get 'em back.
I suppose I could.

Because you see, George, having the keys to Jerry's apartment? 
        That kept me in a fantasy world. Every time I went over to his house, 
        it was like I was on vacation. Better food, better view, better TV. And 
        cleaner? Oh - much cleaner. That became my reality. I ignored the squalor 
        in my own life because I'm looking at life, you see, through Jerry's eyes. 
        I was living in twilight, George. Living in the shadows. Living in the 
        darkness...like you.
Me?
Oh, yeah. I can barely see you, George.

Alright, stop it Kramer, you're freakin' me out. <The waitress 
        comes over.>

Hi, are you ready to order? <George tries to order, but 
        Kramer interrupts.>

character: KRAMER (moves over and sits next to George)
line: Do you ever yearn?
Yearn? Do I yearn?
I yearn.
You yearn.

Oh, yes. Yes, I yearn. Often, I...I sit...and yearn. Have you 
        yearned?

Well, not recently. I craved. I crave all the time, constant 
        craving...but I haven't yearned.
Look at you.
Aw, Kramer, don't start...

character: KRAMER (moving back to the othe side of the booth)
line:
You're wasting your 
        life.

I am not! What you call wasting, I call living! I'm living my 
        life!
O.K., like what? No, tell me! Do you have a job?
No.
You got money?
No.
Do you have a woman?
No.
Do you have any prospects?
No.
You got anything on the horizon?
Uh...no.
Do you have any action at all?
No.

Do you have any conceivable reason for even getting up in the 
        morning?
I like to get the Daily News!

George, it's time for us to grow up - and be men. Not little 
        boys.
Why?
I'm goin' to California. You know, I got the bug.
Yeah, I think I got a touch of something, too.
No, the acting bug. Ever since I was in that Woody Allen movie.

"These pretzels are making me thirsty"? That was one 
        line! You got fired!

I know, I know, but man! I never felt so alive! Now, are you 
        coming with me?
Uh, no, I'm not.

Alright, suit yourself. But let's keep this between us - we're 
        key brothers now. <Gets up to leave.>
You're not really gonna go to California, are you?
Up here, I'm already gone. <Kramer exits.>

Anyway, so he gave me his spare keys, now he wants to have my 
        keys, so I need mine back from you.
Just 'cause you have his keys? Why does he need yours?
I don't know. He said he wants to be my "key brother."
That's ridiculous.
That's Kramer.
I'll give you back your spare keys - but now I want mine back.
What for?
'Cause. I'll give 'em to Jerry.
Jerry? Why?
'Cause he gave me his.
So what?
So, if he has my keys, I should have his.
Well, I don't see why if you have his, he should have yours.
I just said the same thing to you.
What?
What?

Alright, listen, I'll give you your spare keys, but I don't have 
        them with me. Can I please have mine to give to back to Kramer?

Yeah, O.K. I'll go get 'em. <George begins to leaf through 
        papers on Elaine's counter.> What are you doing? Would you just put 
        that down? <Takes the papers away from George.> I gotta get some 
        new friends.
Did you bring the keys?

Yes, but I still don't feel right about letting you into Kramer's 
        apartment without his permission.
This could be an emergency!
You never should have taken away his keys!

I tried to give 'em back, he wouldn't take 'em. <Jerry and 
        George go out into the hallway to Kramer's apartment.>
How'd the Mets do?
They lost.
Kramer?
Hello, boys.
Hello, Newman.
You lookin' for someone?
Don't play coy with me, Newman, I'm not in the mood!
Coy? I'm not being coy.
Is he being coy?
Yeah, coy.
You're being coy. Now where's Kramer, Newman?
Who?
Listen, Tiny. I wanna know where Kramer is and wanna know now!
Alright, go ahead and hit me, Seinfeld. I got witnesses.
Turn around, George.
Sure. <Turns around.>
George?

Now, you better tell me where Kramer is, or are we gonna have 
        to do this the hard way? <Hits wall with his fist.>
Help! Help!
Where's Kramer?
HELP! <Elaine enters.>
What's going on?
They're gonna beat me up!
No we're not.
We're trying to find out what happened to Kramer.

You wanna know what happened to Kramer? I'll tell you what happened 
        to Kramer. He was ticked off. About the keys. Yeah, that's right - about 
        the keys. Thought he got a bad rap.
Bad rap?
Yeah. From you.
Me?

You heard me. So he packed it up and split for the coast. La-La 
        Land. L.A.
L.A.?

I never should have taken his keys away. But he drove me to it! 
        I had no choice! He wouldn't take 'em back. Elaine, you saw it, remember? 
        I said, 'Take the keys back.' He wouldn't do anything. You saw it, didn't 
        you see it?

Yeah, yeah, I saw it. <mutters under her breath> I mean, 
        it's complete bullsh*t.
Huh?
What...?
No, what'd you say?
Nothing. I didn't say anything.
Oh, you didn't see it.
Yeah, I saw it. I saw it! I did, I saw it. Yep.
I heard you say something, there.
I didn't say anything.

I'm calling Kramer's mother. <Picks up the phone, dials.> 
        (To Elaine) I don't know what you said. But it was something. I heard 
        something. Hello? Hello, Mrs. Kramer? Mrs. Kramer? Could you turn the 
        music down? Could you turn the music down!
Ask her about Kramer.
She's drunk out of her mind.

character: JERRY (leaving a message on Elaine's machine)
line:
Elaine? Are you there? 
        It's me, I'm locked out of my apartment, I need my spare keys. Where are 
        you? I'm at the coffee shop.
Hey! You ever been in an accident?

About five years ago. I was going down this very road. Same time 
        of day, going about the same speed I'm going now...there was a rock in 
        the road. Couldn't have been more than a pebble. Never really saw it! 
        Lost control of the bike, went flyin' about a hundred feet - came down 
        right on my head. Cracked it wide open! Blood and stuff was just splattered 
        all over the road, there...I broke every bone in my face. Hey, you know, 
        when they found me, my eyes were hanging out of their sockets? Yeah, they 
        pronounced me dead at the scene. I was in a coma for...well, they told 
        me about a year...said I'd be a vegetable for life. Yeah, but I showed 
        'em. Ever since then I always wear a helmet! <The biker goes into a 
        turn.> Lean! <Kramer yells.>

Georgie Boy! Way to come through with the keys! Sit 
        down, I'm buying you dinner.

Look, I gotta tell ya...I been thinkin' about it, I just don't 
        feel right about letting you into Elaine's apartment.
Don't feel right? What are you talking about?

Well, you know, I shouldn't have let you into Kramer's, now you 
        want to go into Elaine's...she entrusted me with her spare keys, how can 
        I just let you in?
What is the big deal?

Just because you have someone's spare keys, it doesn't entitle 
        you to break into their apartment. That's the reason you took away Kramer's 
        keys.

First of all, you're not even supposed to have Elaine's keys. 
        You're supposed to give 'em back to her, so she can give 'em back to me, 
        because she has mine. So technically, those are my keys.

Yes, well, if you had never taken your keys back from Kramer, 
        he never would have taken his back from you and given 'em to me, in which 
        case I wouldn't have had to take mine back from her.
Well, I want those keys. <Tries to grab the keys from George.>
Nope, no can do.

George, give them to me, I want these keys. <They struggle 
        over the keys.> I don't want to get physical!
Do you wanna fight?
Do you wanna fight?
I'll fight ya! Not the face! Not the face! <The struggle continues.>

And then, the evil ogre took back the magical keys from the handsome 
        young prince.
Oh no. He didn't take back the keys, no way.

Yes! And then the handsome young prince was cast out into the 
        cruel, cruel world.
Oh man, what a bummer. That ogre dude's pretty cold, huh?
Oh, he's cold.

Lemme tell you something, Kramer. If that ogre dude pulled 
        that crap on me <pulls out a knife> - I'D STAB HIM! I'D CUT HIM 

        IN HALF! I'D GUT HIM LIKE A FISH, MAN! That's what I'd do!

Yeah, yeah...that'd be funny. (To driver) Hey, you can drop me 
        here!
Hey, what's the rush, man?
Well, you know, I gotta be goin' now.
Hey, Kramer - have you ever killed a man?

What do you think, junior? You think these hands have been soakin' 
        in Ivory liquid? <mimics choking somebody>

Don't leave, Kramer, stay with us. You know so much about 
        the world, we need you, please Kramer! (they all start chanting) Please, 
        Kramer! Please, Kramer! <Scene ends with Kramer trying to escape their 
        clutches.>

Don't you see? You're just avoiding the middle man. You were gonna 
        give her her spare keys, so she was gonna give 'em to me. So, all that's 
        happening is that instead of giving them to her, you're giving them to 
        me. It's just unfortunate that when she gave you yours, you didn't give 
        her hers. 'Cause then she would have given 'em to me, because she has 
        mine. So then I would have never had to ask you for hers, so that I could 
        get mine.

You're right, how did I miss that? <Begins unlocking the door, 
        mutters under his breath> Maybe because it's a crock of sh*t.
What's that?
Nothing.
I heard something.
Didn't say anything. (They go into Elaine's apartment.)
So, how long you been drivin' this thing?
Goin' on four years.
Well, nothin's sexier than a woman behind the wheel of a semi.

Nothin'? (They exchange a glance, then laugh.) Listen to you, 
        you're quite the sweet-talker.

You know, I always wanted to drive the big rigs. I used to watch 
        those commercials during the reruns of Gomer Pyle.
You want to give it a try?
Really?
Do you know how to double-clutch?
Yeah.

Well, come on! <They trade places and Kramer gets behind the 
        wheel. Kramer turns out to be really rusty on the ol' double-clutch.>
They were in here, I saw her put 'em in here!
Well, this is great.
Well, what do they look like?

They look like keys, George. They look exactly like keys. (In 
        disgust) "What do they look like."
Well, they're obviously not here.
Well, they've gotta be here somewhere.

Jerry, unless I pull down on this statuette and a hidden wall 
        opens up, we have checked every square inch of this apartment!

character: JERRY (looking through some papers on the desk)
line:
What is this? "Murphy 
        Brown"?
What?
By Elaine Benes?
What?
Elaine's writing a "Murphy Brown"?
Lemme see this. (Tries to grab the papers.)
Wait a second! (They fight over the paper.)
Gimme half!
All right, here!
Why didn't she tell us?

Elaine is writing a sitcom...! <Elaine enters 
        the room behind Jerry and George. Jerry spots her and tosses his half 
        of the script at George. George throws it back and paper goes flying everywhere.>
You weasels!
What? What?
How dare you!
We hardly read anything!
It was funny!

Who gave you permission to come into my house and just go through 
        all my things? You thought it was funny?
Well... <picks up some of the pages> From what I saw...
Well, it's just a first draft!
I was locked out of my apartment, I'm just trying to get my keys.
Why did you let him in?! <Shoves George.>
He forced me to!
I did not!
Yes you did!
You! Get out! Get out! Get out!
Elaine, wait! I need my spare keys!
Here! Here's your damn keys, you keep 'em! I don't want 'em anymore!
Good!
And I want my keys back from you!
What, you don't want me to hold your keys?
No, you can't be trusted!
Alright, alright, fine. <Gives the keys to Elaine.>
And I don't want you to hold mine!
Good! I won't!
Good! Don't! Are these my keys?
These aren't my keys!
Whose are these?
I don't know!
I just thought I could write it.
Is that something you want to do?
I don't know. Those writers make a lot of money.

Elaine, let me tell you something about show business. It's hard 
        work! You don't just write a "Murphy Brown." You gotta watch 
        the show, study it, get a sense of the characters, how they relate to 
        each other.

O.K., can I just watch the show? <mutters under her breath> 
        God, what an asshole.
What did you say?
I didn't say anything.

I heard something. <Looks at the TV> Elaine, Elaine! It's 
        Kramer! Kramer's on "Murphy Brown"!
Kramer's on "Murphy Brown"!
Look, there he is, he's sittin' at the desk!
Hi, I'm Murphy Brown, you must be my new secretary.
Oh, good morning, Miss Brown.
And you are...?
Oh, I'm uh, Steven Snell.
Snell. Well, hello, Mr. Snell.
Steven.
Steven. Are you familiar with this computer system?
Oh - I'm familiar with it.

Steven Snell? I know people...and I have a very good 
        feeling about you. <exits.>
Ken Tremblay (briepisken@sympatico.ca)
Larry Charles and Tom Cherones
Andrew Scheinman
Larry David and Jerry Seinfeld
Larry David
Tom Cherones

Jerry Seinfeld, Michael Richards, Jason Alexander, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, 
        Wayne Knight (as Newman), Bob Balaban (as Russel) Heidi Swedberg (as Susan), 
        Kevin Page (as Stu), Len Lesser (as Uncle Leo), Steve Eastin (as cop #1), 
        David Graf (as cop #2), Al FAnn (as judge), Stephen McHattie (as psychiatrist), 
        Peter Blood (as Jay) and Julie Bloom (as receptionist)
        ================================================================
Where the hell did I put this?
What are you looking for?

The remote, the remote, I can't find the remote. Did I lost, I 
        lost it. Did you take it? Did you put it some place?
No, no, no.
All right, what is this?
what is what?
All right, very funny. I get it.
You're in a weird mood.
Come on. Go back to your apartment and fix it.
Fix what?
Your pants!
what is this? What have I got one pant leg on for?

Don't you know? Look-look at your face! You only shaved the right 
        side of your face! What is this? A joke?
No, t's a joke.. a joke... a joke... you think this is funny?
Go look at your face in the mirror.
Wha-huh-wha-huh...
yeah?
It's George.
Come on up.
I don't believe this.
You mean, you didn't know you were doing any of these things?
No, I swear.

I bet this is from that kick from that crazy Joe Davola. You better 
        see a doctor and get some X-rays.
Ah! You're just the man I'm looking for.
Me?
Yeah, here you go.
What's this?
A dry-cleaning bill?
From that woman at NBC?
Yeah.
A dry-cleaning bill for what?
For vomiting on her vest!
Oh, come on George! I didn't do that on purpose!
Well, I shouldn't have to pay for it!

Well, neither should I! Jerry's the one who left the milk in 
        the refrigerator.
Yeah, your milk.
He drank it.
I didn't know.
All right, well, we should all chip in I guess.
Yeah.
How much was it to clean the vest?
Eighteen dollars.
Can you get vomit out of suede?
I don't know.
Yo-yo Ma!
What? Yo-yo Ma?
What about him?
You just said 'Yo-yo Ma'.
What's Yo-yo Ma?
He's a cellist. (to Kramer) You should see a doctor today.
All right, come on, come on, let's go. Six dollars.
I can't believe she sent you that dry-cleaning bill.
I know!
That doesn't really bode well for the show, does it?

The show! Forget about the show! We should take the idea to a 
        different network

Oh, yeah. Right. Like anybody's ever gonna do this! How did you 
        get me to go along with that? A show about nothing!

It was a good idea. Susan liked it. Now, if he hadn't vomitted 
        all over her, we'd be writing it right now.
Jeez!
Anyway.

What are you doing? What's wrong with you? What're 
        you doing? Give me that phone! Go to your apartment and lie down, I'll 
        make an appointment for a doctor today.
What?
NBC! They wanna have another meeting about the idea.

They wanna have another meeting? They wanna buy it?! They wanna 
        but it?! Oh! I tell you! We're gonna be rich!! What are we gonna get for 
        this? Fifty, sixty thousand?
I don't know about sixty.

Oh, it's gotta be fifty! Hee hee! You know how much Ted Danson 
        makes, huh?
Ted Danson! Now, how are you comparing us to Ted Danson?
I didn't say 'We're Ted Danson.'
Yes, you did. You said 'We're Ted Danson'!
Oh!
You know, I think he wears a piece.
Yeah, don't worry. He can afford it.

I'm ten minutes slow again! That's it for this piece of junk! 
        I've had it.
What, is that the one your parents gave you?

Yeah! But it never works. You know we're supposed to be there 
        by two o'clock. We should take a cab.
All right, we'll be a little late, I,m not taking a cab.
I'll pay for it.
It's not the money!
Well, what is it you object to? The comfort? The Speed? The convenience?
Jerry!
Uncle Leo!
Helloooo!
Hello there, how're you doing?
Ha ha! How are you?
Good, good.
How's your mom and dad?
Good, fine.

What are you getting to be too much of a big shot now to give me 
        a call? I don't hear from you anymore!
Oh, no. I've been kinda busy. It's all.
You know where I just came from?
Oh, sure. Danny.

He used to be in the pajama business. I used to be able to get pajamas 
        for free. I used to come over and get pajamas all the time!
Oh, yeah, yeah. I remember.
I-I'm sorry Uncle Leo, I really gotta get going.
Oh. Well. You gotta get going, so go.
We, we got a big meeting with the president of NBC.
Nobody got a gun to your head!
Yeah, I'm really sorry, uh.
Go. Really. I understand. You got an appointment, go to your appointment.
I'm sorry, really.
You know, I know plenty of people in Hollywood too!
Sorry, really.
Yeah?
Come on, are you ready? Let's go!
For what?

What's the matter with you? I just talked to you fifteen minutes 
        ago.
what about?

The courthouse. You gotta go with me to the courthouse. I'm contesting 
        a ticket today.
I can't, I'm going to the doctor's later.

You gotta go with me. I mean, you-you're my alibi. You have to 
        take the stand.
Well, I can't!

Well, let me remind you of something. You wouldn't be here if 
        it wasn't for me and my helmet. I saved your life! You would be dead! 
        Dead! You would cease to exist! You would be gone for the rest of eternity! 
        You wouldn't even begin to comprehend what that means!!
Shut up! I'll get my coat!

You see the look on my uncle's face? Did you see how insulted 
        he was? What could I do? Waht are we supposed to do? You can't leave. 
        There's no excuse good enough to justify walking away from a conversation 
        with one of my relatives.
I didn't shave this morning. I don't feel like myself.
Look at this.
Why didn't you shave this morning?
'Cause I shaved yesterday in the afternoon.
Why?
Because of the day before. It's a long story.
Is that Joe Davola?
It's not him!
I can't live tlike this. I'm being stalked.
Mister Seinfeld? They're ready for you.
Oh.
Mister Seinfeld? What about Mister Costanza? I'm not here?

All right. Look. Now, you promised you're gonna be a little more 
        flexible on the nothing idea, okay? Jsut a little.
Okay. A little.
Okay, you're all set? You got your story?
No.

When the cop stopped me, I told him that I was rushing home because 
        my friend was about to commit suicide.
Uhm...

Now, you're that firend. Now, all we need is a reason why you 
        were going to commit suicide.
I never had an air conditioner.

Even if you're not gonna soap up, at least pretend for my benefit.

Well, I think Poppie's got some problems. There's a whole other

Well, I'm not gonna need this anymore. I got Olive. (Jerry

Olive?

Yeah. My lady friend down at Monks. You guys ought to see the

Hid? I have no idea how this suit got misplaced. Nevertheless,

I hope you rot in that suit. I'm gonna get you for this. I don't

Oh, I'll pay. Half-price. Arrivederci my fellow 40-short.
Monks]

Yeah, all right. Go ahead. (not very interested)

There's this blind guy at a party I was at, and he felt my face

Hum... ok, what else you got?
OK, I'm not gonna tell you the rest of the list.
Oh, because I didn't think the blind guy did it?
Because you have an attitude.
Oh!
Georgio! Nice duds!

You're telling me. (he walks around and the suit makes a swooshing

Did you hear something?
Yeah, like a swoosh.
Yeah.

It must be the fabric. It's rubbing between you thighs when you

I probably didn't hear it on the way over because of the street 
        noise. (he panics) This is no good! I got to meet these guys from 
        MacKenzie for lunch in half an hour!
So what? What would they care?

This MacKenzie, he's a bit of a nut. Someone told me he fired

So you think you're not gonna get the job because your pants make

Let's say it comes down to me and one other guy. He's got a nice

You know, I think all these interviews are making you nuts.
Hey Jerry, I saw your girlfriend was in here before.
Audrey?
Yep. Sat down, had herself a piece of pie.
Was it apple?
What else?
This woman is bending my mind into a pretzel!
Do I know you?
Hmm... No you don't.

Yeah! You were wearing a G-string and one of those bras with

The mannequin!
Oh, I got to see this thing.
Rinitze]
Boy, the resemblance is uncanny.

You think you can pose me however you want? That's my ass in

It's our store and our mannequin, we can do whatever we want

(to Jerry) Yeah? What law am I breaking?
Well, I believe there's some legal precedent - Winchell vs. Mahoney,
Uh-huh
The Charlie Macarthy hearings.

I'm getting the manager. (she leaves)
Jerry get the car. (she's getting the mannequin)
What are you doing?
Just get the car!
Elaine, as your legal counsel I must advise against this.
Jerry's car]

Poppie's
a restaurant]

No, I didn't hear anything.

Huh, that's strange. (they start walking again) It's

The apple pie you had today at Monks

Board of health, we've had several complaints.

at the restaurant with MacKenzie]

No problem there. Conformity is an obsession with me.
Chocolate cream pie. Compliments of the house.

(to George) The chef said that he made it special for

Monk's]
So you didn't get the job.

No. But I was the only one at the table that didn't get violently

Tell her you lost your itch.
What happened to your itch?

I lost it two days ago. I've been faking it so I wouldn't hurt

Well you should tell her.

I'll let her down easy. All right. (he gets up and walks to

Someone else?
Yeah, yeah, yeah...

Her. (he points to the Elaine mannequin in Jerry's car)
her?

Well, it's a style. (turns back to Jerry) Jerry give me

The building where Ricky works. Ricky's the guy in "The

Courtney Cox (Meryl)

Of all the places that you go all the time, 
        the dry-cleaning relationship is one of the most bizarre. Because you 
        keep giving each other the same thing, back and forth, over and over again. 
        He gives it to you, you give it to him, he gives it back to you. It's 
        like it's half his shirt, in a way. He has it as much as you do...you 
        oughta go shopping with him. 'What do you think of this shirt?' 'That 
        would look good with a light starch.' The only warning label people really 
        respect is 'dry-clean only.' Y'know what I mean? Speed limits, lung cancer, 
        cigarette warnings - your very life is at stake! People go, 'Ah, the hell 
        with it!' But dry-clean only? 'Oh, don't put that in the wash! It's dry-clean 
        only! Are you crazy?!'
Good morning.
Good morning.
How'd you sleep?

Hey, you are the couch tonight, young lady. You were all over 
        my side.
I was not!
C'mon, I was sleeping with one cheek off the bed!
By the way, you're falling way behind on the 'I love you's.'
No, it's 15-8.
I know I can't beat ya, I'm just trying to stay competitive.
Alright c'mon, let's get some breakfast.

Uh, let me get a coat. I think I'll try a sport jacket and scarf 
        thing, you know, like an unemployed actor. <Goes into his room, and 
        comes back out with the jacket on.> Haven't worn this one in a long 
        time.
Ooh, cashmere?

No, gore-tex. It's new. <Checks his pockets.> Hey, look 
        at this locket. What the hell is this? There's a picture in here, look 
        at that.
Wow, this is really old. You don't know whose it is?

No, I haven't worn this jacket since I got it back from the dry-cleaner. 
        Maybe we should ask him.
Alright, we'll stop over there.
Yeah. What do you want to get for breakfast?
Pancakes.
Oh now, c'mon, you know I'm getting pancakes.
I don't know that!

But we can't both get pancakes, it's embarrassing. It's like one 
        step from the couples who dress alike.
I'll get the short stack.

Ah, that's why I love ya. 15-9. <They go out into the hallway 
        and run into Kramer and his African-American girlfriend, Anna.> Hey, 
        how ya doin.'
We just got back from breakfast. The pancakes were dynamite.
Hey, is that my maple syrup? <Kramer hands it over.>
You bring your own syrup?
Got to.
You got a lot to learn about pancakes.

This is my wife. She died eight years 
        ago. I been looking all over for this!

Boy, it's a lucky thing I put the jacket on. But how did it get

Well, see here, the chain is broken...it must have slipped in

Oh, wow.

I turned my house upside-down looking for this! It's all I have

Oh, that's so touching.

Know what I'm gonna do for you? I'm gonna give you 
        and your family 25% off all your dry-cleaning from now on.
Oh, come on!
What are you talkin' about?
It's silly!
Hey, forget it!
Get outta here!
It's done!
Alright.
Well, I guess I get it too, because I'm his wife.
I didn't know you were married.
Oh...yeah...you've never met my wife, Meryl? Meryl Seinfeld.
Sure, you get the discount, too.
You might regret that, because the money my wife spends on clothes...
I'm taking him to the cleaners!

Ah - see the sense of humor? C'mere, I'm so nuts about you...<hugs 
        Meryl.> I tell ya, it was fun being single, but when you meet a woman

Oh, hi Greg.
Haven't seen you in a while.

Yeah. Well, today was the first day I worked out since the Central

You ran the Mini-Marathon?
No, but I exercised that day. <Laughs.>
Well, I gotta take off.

Yeah, I guess as an airline pilot, you're one of the few people

Eleven-thirty.
Eleven-thirty?
Wait, ten-thirty. Sorry.
Oh.
Do you have to be somewhere?
No.
Then what are you doing?
I'm just waiting for my friend George, we worked out together.
Oh. Well, it was good seeing you.
Yeah, nice to see you, too.
Uh, would you, um...can I...
Pardon?
The syrup. Would you pass the syrup?

Oh, you want to try the syrup! <Meryl

Can I get you anything else?
Um, yeah...I think my wife and I'll have a little more coffee.
Okay.
And a check for my husband.
To my beautiful wife.
To my adoring husband.
Adoring? What about handsome?
I like adoring.

Sure, adoring's good for you, what does it do for me? <Meryl

line:
Excuse me...where did you

I, uh...well...

Uh, we don't allow any outside syrups, jams or condiments in the

Well, I told my wife not to bring it.
Really? 25% off? Do I get that, too?
No, just Meryl.
Why, why? Why does she get it?
"My wife has an inner ear infection."
See?

I like that! Hey look, will you do me a favor? Will you take

Oh come on, we're gonna start doing this now? I can't be taking

C'mon, just this one time! It's expensive!
Alright. <Elaine enters.>

Hey. Hey Elaine, what do you say if neither of us is married

Let's make it fifty.
We're engaged! Alright, I'm gonna get my quilt. <Kramer leaves.>

Alright, listen to this. Remember that guy I was telling you

The fly-boy.
Yeah.
Hey, where's George? I thought he was with you.

I waited, he didn't show up. Anyway, this guy gave me an open-lip

So?

So? We've always just kind've pecked. This one had a totally

Really.

Yeah. I mean, his upper lip landed flush on my upper lip. But

Moisture?
Yeah. Definite moisture.
That's an open-lip kiss, alright.

Yeah. Listen, I think he's giving me a big signal...maybe he

Oh, uh...it's George.
Hey, what happened to you?
Nothing...little problem.
Well, what was it? I mean, I was waiting.

Can I come upstairs, please? <Elaine pushes the button and

I mean, maybe he wants to ask me out.
I don't know why you're interested in this guy, he's a jerk.
Because, he doesn't pay any attention to me, and he ignores me.
Yeah, so?
I respect that. <George enters.> Mmm, what happened?
Nothing, I... said it was a little problem.
Yeah? What was it?

Well...I was in the locker room showering, and I...I

Here we go.

Anyway, I think the guy in the shower opposite saw me. He gave

You went...in the shower?

Yeah, so what? I'm not the only one! <Kramer enters with his

Do you go in the shower?
No, never.
Do you?
I take baths.

Well, what was I supposed to do? Get out of the shower, put on

Ever hear of...holding it in?
Oh, no...no, that's very bad for the kidneys.
How do you know?
Medical journals!

Do the medical journals mention anything about standing in a pool

Hello.
Oh, hi...honey.
What are you doing here?
I just thought I'd drop off a few things.

Oh. <Smiles at Marty nervously.> Well, I must have been

Another quilt? Huh? <Uncle Leo enters.>
Jerry!
Uncle Leo!
Hello!
Hello.

So, if you or your wife want to drop by on Wednesday,

Your wife?

character: JERRY (hoping Leo will pick up on the scam)
line: Yeah...my wife.
What are you talking about?
Uh...I got married.

You got married? I wasn't invited? Nobody sends

Well, it was sudden.
Are you ashamed of your uncle? Do I embarrass you?
No, no, it was a small ceremony.
Haven't I always been a good uncle?
Yes, yes, you have.
Who told you when you went to school that you print well?
You did, you did.

When he was younger, he had a beautiful penmanship.

I'm a good printer.

I remember your 'V.' It was like a perfect triangle. Whoa,

I'm glad you're here. This can get really boring. Do you know where

I can find out.
Would ya?
Sure. <Thinks - Ooh, a project. That's a definite signal!>
By the way, you look really great in that leotard.

Oh, thanks. <Thinks - That's no signal, who wouldn't like

Hey, you know what's weird? I think I had a dream about you last

<Thinks - Okay, he open-lips me, he dreams about me, we

Can I have a sip of your water?
Oh, yeah, sure. <Hands Greg her bottle.>

Thanks. <Is about to take a drink, but wipes the neck of the

<Thinks - Oh my God.>
I'm sorry, what were you saying?
It was nothing, forget it. <George enters the gym.>

See that guy right there? I caught him urinating in the shower.

Honey? Could you get me something to drink?

character:
JERRY (from his bedroom hallway, alluding to the fact that she should

line: You're right there.

C'mon, I'm sitting! <Jerry walks to the kitchen, annoyed. Meryl

Honey, what'd you do with the can opener?
I didn't do anything with it.
Well, it's not here, it was here yesterday.
It's in the first drawer.
I'm looking in the first drawer. It's not here.
Yes, it is.

Hey...I'm not stupid. I'm looking in that drawer,

Did I say you were stupid?

Well, wouldn't I have to be? You tell me there's a can

Do you want me to go find it?

Yes. I do. You show me where there's a can

        just fighting with my wife.
Jerry, we just heard, what's going on?
Why the hell didn't you tell us?
Listen, Ma...
It was in here yesterday!
Yeah, that's what I said!
Who is she? When did this happen?

I told her you'd get married. She thought you'd never 
        do it.
Morty, you're talking too loud.
I'm not talking loud!
You're hurting my eardrum.

Well, you must have done something 
        with it!
I'm on the phone!
Is she there? Can we talk to her? What's her name?
Mom, I'm not married.
What?
I'm not married!
I knew it, I told ya!
Uncle Leo said.
I'm just pretending I'm married to get a discount on dry-cleaning.
A discount on dry-cleaning?

character:

line:
Could you make a little more noise? <To his parents>

Well, I give up.

Well, whoopie whoop. <Meryl goes into the other room. Kramer

Got any coffee?

Yeah. <Kramer lurches into the kitchen, trips, and falls onto

My quilt is still at the cleaners. Jerry, I can't sleep without

What is that? <Points to Kramer's pocket as Meryl comes back.>
Oh, I forgot. <Hands back Jerry's can opener.>
Hey, I'm sorry about all that can opener stuff.
Yeah, me too. Love you.
Love you.
Well, goodnight.

Goodnight. <They kiss goodnight, then promptly roll away from 
        each other and go to sleep.>
They could kick me out of the health club if he tells them!
So what do you want me to do?
Talk to him!
How can I do that?
You said the guy gave you an open-lipped kiss!

character: ELAINE (enunciating clearly so George gets the point)
line:
Yes, but then 

        he wiped his hand on the top of the bottle when I offered him water!
Well, that doesn't mean anything!

Are you kidding? That's very significant! If he was interested 
        in me, he'd want my germs! He'd just crave my germs!
She's right, George. Bottle-wipe is big.
Well, what about the open-lipped kiss?
Bottle-wipe supercedes it.

Yeah, you're right, you're right. <To Elaine> Alright, 
        maybe he's not interested, but you still know him - can't you just ask 
        him?

George...but if I ask him now, I will have no chance of going 
        out with him.
Why?
I...I don't know...

Aha. Aha. Could it be because you don't want him to know that 
        you have a friend who pees in the shower, is that it?!
No, that's not it!
Oh, I think it is! I think that's exactly what it is!
Why couldn't you just wait?
I was there! I saw a drain!
Since when is a drain a toilet?!
It's all pipes! What's the difference?!

Different pipes go to different places! You're gonna mix 'em 
        up!
I'll call a plumber right now! <Goes for the phone.>
Alright, can we just drop all the pee-pipe stuff here?
Okay! Okay! I will talk to him. <Kramer enters.>
Jerry, I think that quilt is ready.
Alright.
Well, you gotta pick it up for me!
Alright, I'll pick it up, but it's the last time I'm doin' it!
I'm so tired!
Boy, you don't look good.
Huh? I don't?
No, you look pale.

Pale? Oh my God...I gotta meet Anna's parents today! <The 
        phone rings.>

Hello? Oh, hi honey. <annoyed, weary> Yes, I told him. I'll 
        get it. <George and Elaine give each other a look, then leave Jerry 
        to argue with Meryl on the phone.> Whenever. Okay, I'm sorry...
I'm sorry, it's not ready yet. <Kramer bursts in.>

Not ready? It has to be ready! What kind of a business are you 
        running here?
Who the hell are you? It's not your quilt.

He's a very good friend of mine, he's kind've like an older brother 
        to me...when things don't go right, he kinda takes it personally.
Well, uh...maybe tomorrow.
Maybe.
Oh, it's okay, it'll be okay.
Alright, I'm gonna see you later.
Where you goin'?

I gotta meet Anna's parents today, remember? I look terrible! 
        I'm gonna hit the tanning machines.

I can't believe you still do that. You know those things are bad 
        for ya.
Hey, that's how I maintain my glow.

I'm goin' home. <Kramer exits. An attractive woman enters the 
        dry-cleaners with a bundle of clothes in her hands. Jerry notices her

character: PAULA (to Marty, in a foreign accent)
line:
Excuse me? Uh, how much would 
        it cost to clean this?
Oh, about thirteen dollars.
Thirteen? Well, I can't afford that.
Well, I'm sorry.
Hi, Greg.

Hey, Elaine. I'll be off in a second. <Another guy approaches 
        the exercise machine.>

I got the machine next, buddy. <Greg finishes up his workout 
        and gets off the machine.>

It's all yours. <Walks away. Elaine looks at the 
        machine, then George runs over.>
What happened? Did he bring it up?
Never mind that, look at the signal I just got.
Signal? What signal?

Lookit. He knew I was gonna use the machine next, he didn't wipe 
        his sweat off. That's a gesture of intimacy.

I'll tell you what that is - that's a violation of club rules. 
        Now I got him! And you're my witness!

Listen, George! Listen! He knew what he was doing, this was a 
        signal.
A guy leaves a puddle of sweat, that's a signal?
Yeah! It's a social thing.

What if he left you a used Kleenex, what's that, a valentine? 
        Now you go up to him and you tell him that if he's thinking of turning 
        me in, that I got the goods on him!
No! I won't be a party to this.
So you're gonna let me get suspended for shower urination?

Okay, I'll talk to him. But you're putting me in a very difficult 
        position. <Walks away.>
I won't let you do this!
I want to!
But it isn't right! I can't.
Give me the clothes.
Jerry, please. What about her?

Oh, the hell with her. <Paula dramatically flees from the coffee 
        shop. Jerry thinks for a second, then follows her and catches up to her 
        on the street.>
No, Jerry, please!
I'm not gonna let you walk out of my life.

I can't fight you. <They embrace and 
        kiss passionately.>
Do you want box or hanger?
You decide. <Jerry considers.>
You're really working up quite a sweat today, huh?

Paris huh?

Yea, ya..ya know I feel terrible about Joey but it's jus..it's 
        a great business opportunity. I-I don't even know how long I'm gonna be 
        away for.
Where will you stay?

An apartment complex, the uh the Eiffel Towers. uumm Like I said 
        uh you'll be getting a postcard uh in a few days and again I'm sorry.
George, you have no idea how fantastic this is.
Fantastic?

Ya, we've been trying to reunite Joey with his father who lives 
        in Paris. But he's afraid to fly alone, you know he's kinda withdrawn, 
        but he seems to take to you. (George smiling in surprise) So it's a perfect 
        solution.
How gee what a coincidence.
And you'll send me a postcard.

Helen really seemed to respond to Renoir. I think she really connected 
        to the way he painted children.
Mm hmm.

And that Morty, I'll tell ya that guy is full of life. (laughs) 
        He was convinced Monet was near sighted. I kept telling him
Aaron
Yes?

Uh, let me ask you a question. How come you asked Mr. and Mrs. 
        Seinfeld to go to the museum with you?

Well, they were in from out of town, I thought they would enjoy 
        it.

Uhuh, um you didn't feel uncomfortable spending the whole day 
        at the museum with two complete strangers who were more than twice your 
        age?
No, it was fun.
You had fun with Mr. and Mrs. Seinfeld.
Yea, they bought me a coke.
So how'd you come up with the idea for the belt-less trench coat?

I came home one night, and I tripped over one of Jerry's toys. 
        (Jerry smiling points to himself and nods with cards in his hands) So 
        I took out my belt just to threaten him, and I got a glimpse of myself 
        in the mirror.
How serendipitous.
So that night I cut off the loops and the Executive was born.
Mmm

He also came up with an idea for a brimless rain-hat but that 
        never materialized. (to Morty) Alright come on let's play.
Did you call Jack Klompus yet?
I haven't been able to reach him. Hey I'll call him right now.
Ah come on.
Just a second. (Goes to grab the phone)
Jerry have you seen Schindler's List?
No I haven't seen it yet.
Oh you have to go you have to
I'm going
You have to
Ok
(on the phone) Hello Jack.
Ya
It's Morty
Who died?

Nobody died. Jack I want you to do me a big favor. (Jerry holding 
        up some cards looking at his father) In my garage there are a couple of 
        boxes.
What boxes?
I'm gonna explain what boxes.
Alright how the hell do I know?

Anyway there are these three big boxes, you can't miss them. I 
        want you to ship them here to New York for me.
I thought you're going to Paris
I'm still going to Paris. I got a big deal cooking here.
What's in the boxes?
Raincoats.

Raincoats? (Doris sighs) You think you're gonna sell those old 
        crappy raincoats? That's garbage.
I guarantee you Doris is not letting him mail those boxes.
When do you want these?
Send them tomorrow.
You think they're coming tonight?
I dunno they said maybe.

Of course they're coming, they're leaving soon. If they don't 
        come tonight they might not see us.
Well they better come, I got all this Paella.

I admire Morty and Helen going to France. We should take a trip, 
        maybe a cruise.
Yes a cruise, a long cruise, just the two of you.
Georgie what were you doing poking around the attic last night?
I-I wasn't in the attic.
I heard noise.
Maybe it was a mouse.
(jumping to his feet) OK that's it! We're moving!
What?
I will not tolerate infestation.
You haven't even seen one.

Don't you understand the very thought, the very idea, I'll never 
        be comfortable again.

character:
Directed by Tom Cherones. Written by Larry Charles.
        Guest stars
line:
Melanie Chartoff (Robin)
        Veanne Cox (Toby)
        Dom Irrera (Ronnie)
        Jon Favreau (Eric the Clown)
        Lisa Pescia (Joanne)
        Hiram Kasten (Michael)
        Patience Cleveland (Robin's mother)
        Lawrence LeJohn (Fireman)
        Jerry Stiller (Frank Costanza, voice only)
        Estelle Harris (Estelle Costanza, voice only)

To me, the thing about birthday parties is that 
        the first birthday party you have and the last birthday party you have 
        are actually quite similar. You know, you just kinda sit there...you're 
        the least excited person at the party. You don't even really realize that 
        there is a party. You don't know what's goin' on. Both birthday parties, 
        people have to kinda help you blow out the candles, you can't do it...you 
        don't even know why you're doing it. What is this ritual? What is going 
        on? It's also the only two birthday parties where other people have to 
        gather your friends together for you. Sometimes they're not even 
        your friends. They make the judgement. They bring 'em in, they sit 'em 
        down, and they tell you - 'these are your friends! Tell them thank you 
        for coming to my birthday party.'

These are great! Just great! Really great! Really, 
        really great! Don't you think so, Elaine?
Yeah, really great.

A coffee table book about coffee tables! <To Kramer> How 
        did you come up with this idea?
It was there!

Oh, look at this one! It's saying, 'I'm a coffee table, put some 
        coffee on me! Oh, the hotter the better, that's what I'm here for!' <laughs>
Actually, I've got some work I gotta do, so...

Hey, how about if the book came with these little fold-out legs...so 
        the book itself becomes a coffee table?
Ohhh, that is a great idea! Really, really great!

'And that coffee table is saying, put some coffee 
        on me!' I'd like to put some coffee on her. Hot, scalding coffee - right 
        in her face! I swear! This is like working with a contestant from "The 
        Price Is Right"! <demonstrates>

Yeah, that's real interesting. Elaine, listen, tell me if you 
        think this is funny - <reads comedy he's written> "Men definitely 
        hit the remote more than women...men don't care what's on TV, men only 
        care what else is on TV. Women want to see what the show is before 
        they change the channel, because men hunt and women nest."
Yeah, it's funny, I dunno.
You don't know? Come on, that's gold!
Well, I don't know about "gold."
Oh, that's gold, baby.
'Baby'? What, are you doing George now?
I was saying 'baby' way before George!

Well, I don't know, don't ask me any more questions about jokes, 
        Jerry, it puts too much pressure on me.
Well, this guy Leonard Christian's gonna be there tomorrow night.
Yeah, who's he?

He's a writer from Entertainment Weekly. I would like to 
        have a good show.
Danke schoen, my little dumplings.
Hi.
Hey, how about that Toby, huh?
Yeah, how about her?
Ooh, she's a package full of energy!
Yeah, she's a package full of something.

And that something is life. Jerry, you gotta meet this gal - 
        she's brimmin' with positivity!

Oh, pleeeeease. <moves to the living 
        room and sits down>
Hey, are you performing tomorrow night?
Yeah.
Great, I'm gonna bring Toby.

Well, you better laugh 'cause I'm being reviewed. Leonard Christian's 
        gonna be there.
Oh, she's a great laugher - right, Elaine?

Oh yeah, she's a great laugher, Jerry. <imitates Toby> 
        Really, really great!

Well, you want to sit with George? I think he's coming 
        with Robin.
Is that the waitress from the comedy club?
Yeah.
What about her kid, is she bringing him, too?
She's got a kid?
Yeah, you should see George get along with this kid!

Ow! What are you doing under there? Hey, stop that! Don't eat 
        that! That's not food! <to Robin> He's suckin' down Equal packets!
Do you think 25 kids is too much?

25 kids for his birthday party? <to kid under table> Don't 
        put your tongue on the floor! He's putting his tongue on the floor! Here, 
        here, have some more sugar packets.
So, what about entertainment? <to kid> Should I get Barney?
No Barney!
Maybe a clown.
How about Bozo?
Who's Bozo?

Who's Bozo? Bozo the Clown, that's who Bozo is. When I was a 
        kid, Bozo the Clown was the clown, bar none.
George...
With the orange hair, and the big clown shirt with the ruffles...
George...
And the TV show! He had cartoons!

George! Forget Bozo, George. Bozo's out. He's finished. It's over 
        for Bozo.

You know, when I was a kid, we didn't have these elaborate birthday 
        parties with catered food and entertainment. I remember my 7th birthday 
        party...

character:
We see a flashback of George at seven, sitting in front of a birthday 
        cake with a shocked expression on his face, while Frank and Estelle scream 
        at him

line:
Blow out the candles! Blow out the candles, I said! Blow out 
        the damn candles!
Stop it, Frank! You're killing him!
Well, this time, you can blow out the candles.

Nah, I have asthma. <Robin's kid grabs George's leg from under 
        the table, and George struggles.>
Hi!
Hi, Toby.
How are you doing today?

Fine... <Toby sits and waits for Elaine to speak.> How 
        are you?

Oh, I'm great! Just great. Really great! Oh, hey - did you hear 
        about Bob Rosen?
Nope.
He is going to Knopp. He is going to be a vice president.

Knopp? Really? Boy. That means there's an opening here for senior 
        editor...has Lippman, uh, hired anyone?
No. I hear he wants to promote someone in-house.
Really!
Maybe it'll be you!
Oh...well...

You really deserve it. I mean, you have experience, seniority...Lippman 
        really respects your opinion...
Well! Well, it could be you.
No...
No, really.
Really? You think so?
Sure.
Boy, wouldn't that be exciting!
I mean, stranger things have happened...
Wow! Me! A senior editor! <deadly serious> I'd like that.
Well, you shouldn't get your hopes up, Toby.

Well, it's a possibility, like you said! Stranger things have happened! 
        Thank you, Elaine. Thank you. <Exits.>

Hey, Ronnie. <To bartender> Can I have a club soda? <To 
        Ronnie> Goin' on tonight?
Yeah. You?
Yeah.
You know Leonard Christian's here?
Yeah, I know.
Can I ask you something? Are my nostrils getting bigger?
I don't...think so.
Are you sure? Take a good look. They seem a little bigger?
I don't...I dunno.
Is it possible for nostrils to expand?
Oh, is this a bit?

Hey, I don't do "bits." I'm a prop comic. Dammit, I 
        can't find my water gun. I can't go on without my water gun.
Hey, Jerry. Toby, this is Jerry.

This is so exciting! Look, I have goosebumps! <To Jerry> 
        Touch! Touch them! <Jerry touches her arm. Toby screeches with excitement.> 
        I've never been to a comedy club before!

Really! You know, a lot of restaurants are serving brewed decaf 
        now, too.
You are so funny!
Oh, you'll have a good time, I swear.

Oh! He swears like he thinks I don't believe him. I believe you. 
        I believe you! Oh, he's so funny! <laughs>
What about me?

What about you? <laughs> I'm only kidding. You're 
        funny, too. I love to laugh.
Good, good.
So, you up next?
Yeah, why don't you guys get a table so you'll have good seats?

Oh yeah, we don't want some jerk sitting in front of us, it'll 
        be like, 'Hey, big head, can you move out of the way? I didn't pay a cover 
        charge to stare at your bald spot.' <laughs>
Alright, so you have a good show, huh buddy?
Yeah.
Oh, have a great show. Hey, we'll make sure it's a great show!

O.k., good, I'll see you later. <Kramer and Toby are about 
        to exit. She turns around and clutches Kramer's jacket.>
Oh, he's so great! This is so great! I'm so excited!
Men definitely hit the remote button more than women...
Oh, really! Really! That is so true!

Yes, yeah...see, men don't care what's on TV, men only care what 
        else is on TV.

Yes! Yes! Right on! Right on! <Other audience members give her 
        puzzled looks.>

character: JERRY (attempting to carry on despite Toby's interruptions)
line:
See...women 
        really want to see what the show is before they change the channel...
Oh, that is so true, yes!
...that's why men hunt and women nest.

BOO! BOO! Hiss! Boo! <Toby's obnoxious behavior causes Jerry 
        to completely lose his place and mess up his act.>

Hey, what's the deal? What was goin' on there? I invite you down 
        here, I have an important show, and she heckles me?!
Look, she didn't mean anything.
Well, what is the matter with her? Is she crazy?!
She's just being enthusiastic, that's all!
Hey! What is wrong with you?!
Me? Nothing's wrong with me.

You boo me?! You hiss?! You didn't stop blathering throughout 
        the whole set!
Oh, come on! I thought you're a pro! That's part of the show.

No! Not part of the show! Booing and hissing are not part of the 
        show! You boo puppets! You hiss villains in silent movies!

Well, that's the way I express myself. How are you gonna make it 
        in this business if you can't take it?
Oh, I can take it.
Let's go. <Ronnie walks by Jerry.>
Hey, man. Good set.
Bozo?
No.
B-O-Z-O?
Sorry, I...
You've never heard of Bozo the Clown?
No!
How could you not know who Bozo the Clown is?
I don't know, I just don't.
How can you call yourself a clown and not know who Bozo is?

Hey, man - what are you hassling me for? This is just a gig, it's 
        not my life. I don't know who Bozo is, what - is he a clown?
Is he a clown? What, are you kidding me!?
Well, what is he?
Yes, he's a clown!
Alright, so what's the big deal! There's millions of clowns!
Alright, just forget it.

Me forget it? You should forget it! You're livin' in the past, 
        man! You're hung up on some clown from the sixties, man!

Alright, very good, very good...go fold your little balloon animals, 
        Eric. Eric! What kind of name is that for a clown, huh?

Excuse me...you must be George! I'm Robin's mother. Oh, 
        you seem like such a lovely young man!
Well, I do what I can. <Robin comes over.>
Hi Mom, how's everything?
Oh, this is just a wonderful party!
The burgers should be ready in a minute.

Ah, great, great. <sniffs> What's that smell? Smoke? <walks 
        to the kitchen> Hey everybody, I think I smell some smoke back here...<smoke 
        boils into the doorway.> FIRE! FIRE! Get out of the way!

It was an inferno in there! An inferno! <Eric, 
        Robin's mother, and all the kids rush at George.>

There he is! That's him! <Tries to clobber George with his big 
        shoe.>
That's the coward that left us to die!

I...was trying to lead the way. 
        We needed a leader! Someone to lead the way to safety.
But you yelled "get out of my way"!

Because! Because, as the leader...if I die...then all hope is 
        lost! Who would lead? The clown? Instead of castigating me, you should 
        all be thanking me. What kind of a topsy-turvy world do we live in, where 
        heroes are cast as villains? Brave men as cowards?

But I saw you push the women and children out of the way in a 
        mad panic! I saw you knock them down! And when you ran out, you left everyone 
        behind!

Seemingly. Seemingly, to the untrained eye, I can fully understand 
        how you got that impression. What looked like pushing...what looked like 
        knocking down...was a safety precaution! In a fire, you stay close to 
        the ground, am I right? And when I ran out that door, I was not leaving 
        anyone behind! Oh, quite the contrary! I risked my life making sure that 
        exit was clear. Any other questions?
How do you live with yourself?
Its not easy.
So she doesn't want to see me anymore.
Did you knock her over too, or just the kids?
No, her too. And her mother.
Really? Her mother.
Yeah. I may have stepped on her arm, too, I don't know.
You probably couldn't see because of the smoke.
Yeah. But it was somebody's arm.

So you feel "women and children first," in this day 
        and age, is somewhat of an antiquated notion.
To some degree.
So basically, it's every man, woman, child, and invalid for themselves.
In a manner of speaking.
Well, it's honest.

Yeah. She should be commending me for treating everyone like 
        equals.

Well, perhaps when she's released from the burn center, she'll 
        see things differently.
Perhaps.
So, what was the fire? Just a couple of greasy hamburgers?
Yeah. Eric the Clown put it out with his big shoe.
By the way, did you see this? <Hands George a magazine>
What's that?

It's the Leonard Christian article about my show. Plus my gig 
        in Miami got cancelled, I betcha it's because of the article.

Wow, he really does a number on you. <reads> "Seinfeld 
        froze like a deer in the headlights in the face of incessant heckling."
I should have let her have it! I held back because of Kramer.

You know what you oughta do. You should go to her office and 
        heckle her.
Yeah, right.

You know, like all the comedians always say, 'How would you like 
        it if I came to where you work and heckled you?'
Yeah, that'd be something.
I'm not kidding, you should do it.

But wouldn't that be the ultimate comedian's revenge? I've always 
        had a fantasy about doing that.
Well, go ahead! Do it!
Why can't I?
No reason!

You know what? I think I'm gonna do that! She came down to where 
        I work, I'll go down to where she works!
This is unprecedented!
There's no precedent, baby!
What...are you using my babies now?

Hey, nice shoes. What, you wear sandals to work? It's always nice 
        to walk into a room and get the aroma of feet. That's real conducive to 
        the work atmosphere. I'm sure your co-workers really appreciate it. 'Hey, 
        let's go eat in Toby's office. Great idea! We can check on her bunions!'
You know, I have work to do here! I'm very busy!
Oh, is this disruptive? You find it hard to work with someone...interrupting?
Well, how would you like it if I called security?

Security? Well, I don't know how you're gonna make it in this 
        business if you can't take it! Ya gotta be tough! Booo! Boooo!
Wait a second, what's happenin' here? Toby! Toby!
What did you go up there to heckle her for?

Because she came down to the club and heckled me! Give her a taste 
        of her own medicine! <George enters.>
Oh, YEAH! You gave her a taste of medicine, alright.
Well, I didn't want her to have an accident.
What accident?

Well, after he heckled Toby, she got so upset, she ran out of 
        the building and a street sweeper ran over her foot and severed her pinky 
        toe.
That's unbelievable!

Yeah! Then after the ambulance left, I found the toe! So I put 
        it in a Cracker Jack box, filled it with ice, and took off for the hospital.
You ran?

No, I jumped on the bus. I told the driver, "I got a toe 
        here, buddy - step on it."
Holy cow!

Yeah, yeah, then all of a sudden, this guy pulls out a gun. Well, 
        I knew any delay is gonna cost her her pinky toe, so I got out of the 
        seat and I started walking towards him. He says, "Where do you think 
        you're going, Cracker Jack?" I said, "Well, I got a little prize 
        for ya, buddy - " <Kramer throws two quick punches and a massive 
        uppercut> - knocked him out cold!
How could you do that?!

Then everybody is screamin,' because the driver, he's passed 
        out from all the commotion...the bus is out of control! So, I grab him 
        by the collar, I take him out of the seat, I get behind the wheel and 
        now I'm drivin' the bus.
You're Batman.

Yeah. Yeah, I am Batman. Then the mugger, he comes to, and he 
        starts chokin' me! So I'm fightin' him off with one hand and I kept drivin' 
        the bus with the other, y'know? Then I managed to open up the door, and 
        I kicked him out the door with my foot, you know - at the next stop.
You kept makin' all the stops?
Well, people kept ringin' the bell!
Well, what about the toe? What happened to the toe?

Well! I am happy to say that the little guy is back in place 
        at the end of the line.
You did all this...for a pinky toe?
Well, it's a valuable appendage.
So, Kramer found the toe, and they re-attached it.
Really.
Poor kid. What an ordeal.

And you know how extremely sensitive she is...she's gonna need 
        our full support.
Yeah, right.

Look who's here! Toby! <Toby enters on 
        crutches.>
Toby, what can I do? Can I get you something?
Oh no, I'll be fine...
She got the promotion?
Yep.
Why?

I'll tell ya why. Because of her pinky toe, that's why. Because 
        Lippman felt so sorry for her, he didn't want to hurt her feelings.
Too bad.

Sure, the pinky toe is cute! But, I mean, what is it? It's useless! 
        It does nothing. It's got that little nail that is just impossible to 
        cut. What do we need it for?

Because Elaine, that's the one that goes 'wee-wee-wee all the 
        home.'
Why don't you just shut the f-

Hey Elaine, did you hear the good news? Toby 
        got promoted!
Yes, I heard, Kramer - I work there, remember??

Yeah, and you know what she told me? She said her first order 
        of business is to put my coffee table book into the bookstores as soon 
        as possible.
Oh, wonderful!

You know, throughout this whole thing, she always kept a smile 
        on her face.
Oh, of course! She's deranged.

So, I went down to the magazine, I pleaded with him to come and 
        see me again, finally he agreed to come down tonight, and he's going to 
        write another article.
I heard you went down to somebody's office and heckled them?
Damn right! We've been lapdogs long enough!
How could you do that? I mean, everybody's talking about it.
Well, it's about time one of us drew a line in the sand.

Jerry, you're like Rosa Parks. You opened the door for all of 
        us. I can't wait till the next time someone heckles me.
Yeah, well, won't be long.
Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome Jerry Seinfeld!
Gotta go. <heads out on stage>
Robin? Robin!
George, what is it? I'm working.

Robin, listen to me. The most amazing thing has happened. Kramer 
        has opened my eyes. I think I've changed.
What are you talking about?
O.k....<is about to explain. Cut to Jerry on-stage.>

I mean, Bozo the Clown...does he really need "the clown" 
        in his title, as clown? Bozo, "the" clown? Are we going to confuse 
        him with Bozo the district attorney? Bozo the pope? There's no other Bozo...

...you'll see, things will be different now - if you just give 
        me one more chance.
Listen...I gotta think about this. <walks away.>
Alright, but I'm serious about this.

line:
Alright, hand it over 
        man!
...that's why men hunt and women nest.

He's got a gun! He's got a gun! <Tries to

George! This is Ronnie Kaye!

The prop comic? <Ronnie holds up his water gun and smiles.> 
        Oh, hi...I didn't recognize you, what...did you get a haircut?
Nostrils.
George - could I have a word?

I was in a hotel the other day, and on the 
        back of the door in the hotel they have the fire map. I'm flattered that 
        they think I have it together enough to stand in a burning hotel room 
        memorizing directions. 'Yeah, I'll go left by the stairs, right by the 
        candy machine...' I'd probably get lost, have to go back to the room,

        you do in a hotel fire - do not panic. Hey, I got four minutes to live, 
        I've never panicked in my whole life - it's my option. Even if they find 
        you, you have a perfect excuse...'Gee, I heard they saved you swingin' 
        from the shower curtain naked with an ice bucket on your head. What happened 
        there?' 'Well, I panicked.' 'That's understandable.'
//www.geocities.com/tnguym
Look at the work people do to get to the ocean.
All right, get off at the next exit.

Kramer, I've driven to the Hamptons many times, I know the 
              exit.
It's a great house, pool's something? Yeah, I'll be there.
(To Elaine) You sure we're makin' the right move?

We gotta see the new baby anyway, at least we'll get a

Didn't they just have a baby?

That was two years ago, remember? 'Jeh-Ree, you gotta see 
              the

Is it possible they're just having babies to get people

Hey Jerry, you ever wear silk underwear?
No.
Put that on the top of your list.

No, not for me. A little too delightful. Well, George and

Oh, isn't that weird that George and Jane haven't had sex

I know, George is pretty pleased about it. It's like she 
              signed a
When's Rachel comin' out?
She's makin' the three o'clock train.

Her father is so religious, I'm just amazed that he's letting 
              you
I bought him some kishka.
What's that?

It's kind of a stuffed meat thing. Israeli soldiers carry 
              it. In
I never tasted a cough medicine I didn't love.
Me too. I love cough medicine.

You see? We were made for each other. (Thinking to himself) 
              It's
What's your favorite?
Pertussin. Ever try it with club soda?
No.

Oh, very refreshing. (Thinking again) Sex is like joining

Are we almost there?

Yeah, about ten, fifteen minutes. But I have to stop at

What for?

My mother loves Hampton tomatoes. She's nuts for Hampton

Can you buy 'em later? I really wanna get some... sun.
Hey Jerry. Rub some lotion on my back.
Who are you, Mrs. Robinson?
Come on, I'll rub some on yours.
No, that's no sweet'ning the deal. No.

(To Jane) You know, when I was a kid, I once found a dollar 
              and
(No feeling in her voice) You must've been excited.

Yeah. Hey, you know, I gotta go get these tomatoes. You

I don't think so.
'Kay. I'll uh, I'll see you later. Anybody want some tomatoes?
No thanks.
No. (George leaves for the tomatoes)
I'm gonna take a dip. (She leaves for beach, Elaine enters
And then there's Maude. (She sits down next to Jerry)
Look at my face, look at it. You see any lines?
No lines.

So when're we gonna see this baby? When is the momentous

I don't know. They're takin' a nap or something.

I'm gonna go see if there are any girls on the beach. Elaine, 
              you
(Sarcastic) No thanks. I got plenty of girlfriends.
(Looking toward beach) Oh this is interesting.
What?
Jane's topless. (They all look)
Yo yo ma.
Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
Nice rack. (Carol and Michael inside open back door)
Come on, you guys. You can come on and see the bay-bee!
Oh, in a minute, Carol.
We're gonna be right there.
This is weird wild stuff. George hasn't even seen her yet.
Why do you think we're getting the sneak preview?
Maybe she's trying to create a buzz.
