        why? Why do we think that glasses makes us look more intelligent? Is it 
        from the endless hours of reading and studying and researching that this 
        person supposedly blew out their eyeballs, and that's why they need the 
        glasses? It's just a corrective device. If you see someone with a hearing 
        aid, you don't think, 'Oh, they must have been listening real good...yeah, 
        to a lot of important stuff...' No, they are deaf. They can't hear.

Hey, boys and girls. I need you both to sponsor me in the AIDS 
        walk.
Is that tomorrow?

Yeah, yeah, so...git-git...<gestures to Elaine to sign the 
        form.>
Well, I admire you for joining the fight against AIDS.

Well, if I didn't do something I wouldn't be able to live with 
        myself.
It's hard enough living next door.

I tell ya, there's some people, they just wear a ribbon and they 
        think they're doin' something? Not me. I talk the talk, and I walk the 
        walk, baby. <gets up> I'll be right back.
New jeans?
Yeah.
Still a 31 waist?

Yep. Since college. <Looks at Kramer's AIDS walk list.> 
        Hey, Lena Small's on this list.
Lena Small?

Yeah, that girl I was gonna call for a date, she was unlisted...and 
        now here's her number.

Oh, you're not gonna cop a girl's phone number off an AIDS charity 
        list!

Elaine, you should admire me...I'm aspiring 
        to date a giving person.
You're a taking person.

That's why I should date a giving person. If I date a taking person, 
        everyone's taking, taking, taking, no one's giving - it's bedlam.
She's gonna ask how you got her number.

Oh, I'll tell her I met some guy who knew her and he gave it to 
        me.
What's he look like?

I really didn't pay much attention, I'd just come from buying 
        a speedboat.
You're buying a speedboat?

See, we're already off the subject of how I got her number. <Elaine 
        laughs.> All I gotta do is get past the first phone call and I'm home 
        free.
I don't know about that.

So if Billy had gotten your number off the AIDS walk list, you 
        wouldn't have gone out with him?
Well...
Yeah. So you really like this guy.
Very much.
How's the...sexual chemistry?

Haven't been in the lab yet. But I am birth control shopping 
        today. <Kramer overhears as he returns to the booth.>
Are you still on the pill?
Uh, Kramer...

I'll tell ya, I think birth control should be discussed in an 
        open forum.
The sponge, o.k.? The Today sponge.
But wasn't that taken off the market?

Off the market? The sponge? No, no...no way. Everybody loves 
        the sponge.
I read it in Wall Street Week...Louis, uh, Rukeyser.

Hello, Lena? Hi, it's Jerry Seinfeld. How did I get your number? 
        I met a guy that knows you, he gave it to me...I don't remember his name. 
        Think it began with a W, maybe a Q. I wasn't paying that much attention, 
        I'd just come from shopping for a speedboat...

You know, I really like those new jeans Jerry was wearing. He's 
        really thin.
Not as thin as you think.
Why? He's a 31. I saw the tag on the back.
The tag, huh?
Mmm-hmm.

Let me tell you something about that tag. It's no 31, and uh...let's 
        just leave it at that.
What are you talking about?
He scratches off a 32 and he puts in 31.
Oh, how could he be so vain?

Well, this is the Jerry Seinfeld that only I know. I can't believe 
        I just told you that.
Why not?
Well, Jerry doesn't want anyone to know.

Well, it's alright, I'm your fiance. Everyone assumes you'll tell 
        me everything.
Where did you get that from?
Well, we're a couple. It's understood.
I never heard of that.
Well, you've never been a couple.
I've coupled! I've coupled!
Keeping secrets! This is just like your secret bank code.

This is totally different! That was my secret, this is Jerry's 
        secret! There's...there's attorney-client priveleges here! If I play it 
        by your rule, no one'll ever confide in me again, I'll be cut out of the 
        loop!
Hey.
Hey. What's the matter?
I had a fight with Susan.
What about?

Oh...<is about to tell Jerry, but reconsiders> ...clothing, 
        something, I dunno. So, uh, what are you doing today?
I got a date with that girl, Lena.
Lena, how'd you meet her?

I actually met her a few weeks ago, but... <Jerry stops, and 
        mentally visualizes George telling Susan about how Jerry got Lena's number 
        from the AIDS list...then Susan passing the information along to Monica 
        on the phone at work.>
You met her a few weeks ago, but...?
I didn't call her till today.
So, uh...wanna double?
What?
Well, I just had a fight - I need a group dynamic.
I dunno. <Elaine enters.> Hey.

Well, Kramer was right. My friend Kim told me the sponge is off 
        the market.
So what are you gonna do?

I'll tell you what I'm gonna do - I'm gonna do a hard-target 
        search. Of every drug store, general store, health store and grocery store 
        in a 25-block radius.
Just for these sponges?

Hey man, women are really loyal to their birth control methods. 
        What does Susan use?
I dunno.
You don't know?
I, uh...figure it's something. <Kramer enters.>
What are you all out of breath from?
The elevator just broke. I had to walk up five flights.

And you got the AIDS walk tomorrow. You're never gonna make it, 
        you're in horrible shape.
Hey, I'm in tip-top shape. Better than you!
I got a 31 waist, mister!
Yeah, well I'm walking for charity, what are you doing?

What am I doing? I'm...dating a woman who happens to 
        be sponsoring one of these walkers.
Can I help you?

Yeah, do you have any Today sponges? I know 
        they're off the market, but...
Actually, we have a case left.

A case! A case of sponges? I mean, uh...a case. Huh. 
        Uh...how many come in a case?
Sixty.
Sixty?! Uh...well, I'll take three.
Three.
Make it ten.
Ten?
Twenty sponges should be plenty.
Did you say twenty?
Yeah, twenty-five sponges is just fine.
Right. So, you're set with twenty-five.
Yeah. Just give me the whole case and I'll be on my way.

Hey, I have found the best-smelling detergent. Lena, smell my 
        shirt.
Mmm! Very nice.
It's All-Tempa-Cheer.
I use Planet. It's bio-degradable and doesn't pollute the oceans.
Yeah, the oceans really are getting very sudsy.

Can you wrap up all the left-overs on the table, please? 
        I always take the left-overs. I work in a soup kitchen every morning at 
        6 a.m.
They serve soup at 6 a.m.?
Yeah. That's all they have.
Do the bums ever complain? "Soup again?"
I'd get tired of it.
How could you not?
Guess who volunteered last week?
Mick Jagger.
No. Maya Angelou.
Oh, the poet!

So, let me ask you something - these people eat soup 
        three times a day?
I don't know.
So, did you get to talk to her?
Talk to who?
Is it a lot of cream soups?
Maya Angelou, the poet.
No, I didn't get the chance.

Oh, well, I'm sure you can reach her...she's a poet. What does 
        a poet need an unlisted number for?
I'm going to the ladies room.
I'll go with you. <They leave.>
What are you looking at me like that for?
Why'd you have to mention 'unlisted number'?
What are you talking about?
Alright, I gotta tell you something, but you cannot tell Susan.

Jerry got her phone number off of an AIDS walk list? Oh, that's 
        awful!

I know, but don't say anything to anyone. He told me not to tell 
        you.
But you told me anyway?

Well, you know, I was thinking about what you said before, and...you're 
        right, I've never really been a couple, so...if that's the rule, then 
        I'm gonna go by the rule.
Thank you, honey.
So, you wanna go home and...make up, officially?
Can we stop by a drug store first?
What for?
I'm out of birth control stuff.
Oh, o.k., yeah. Where am I gonna park here...? <Pulls over.>
Oh, don't park. I'll just sit in the car, you can run in.
Me run in? Why don't you run in?
You don't know what I use for birth control, do you?
Of course I do.
You do? What?

You know. You use the, uh...<mutters something unintelligible 
        under his breath.>
The what?
You know, the uh...<mutters it again.>
Just get me some sponges, please.

Wait, wait a minute...they don't have them anymore. I just found 
        out, they just took them off the market.
Off the market? The sponge?
Yeah, so you gotta use something else.
I can't! I love the sponge! I need the sponge!
O.k....<thinks> I think I know where we can get one.
Kramer, what the hell is going on in there?

It's a poker game...<yells to the crowd> And I'm kickin' 
        some serious butt!
Are you out of your mind? You got the AIDS walk tomorrow!
Hey, Kramer - are you in?

Oh, you gotta be kiddin'! You see those two ladies I got showin'? 
        Do they look scared?!
You're never gonna make it!
You, uh...you wanna go in the bedroom?

O.k. Hold on just a second. <Gets up and heads to the bathroom. 
        George knocks at the door.>

Elaine? It's me, George. <Elaine opens the door.> Hey, 
        sorry to bother you so late. <To Billy> Hey! How ya doin.' <To 
        Elaine> Uh, did you get any of those sponges?
Yeah. Cleaned out the whole west side. Why?
Well...Susan.
Ah, Susan uses the sponge.
Susan loves the sponge.
Yeah, I'm sorry, George. I can't help you out.
What?

I can't do it. No way, there's no how. <Tries to push George 
        out the door. George resists.>

Elaine...let me just explain something to you. See, this is not 
        just a weekend routine...I'm on the verge of make-up sex here. You know 
        about make-up sex?

Oh yeah, I know all about make-up sex, and I'm really sorry. 
        <Shoves George into the hallway and closes the door. George blocks 
        the door with his foot.>

Elaine, can I just explain something to you very privately here? 
        Susan and I have been together many, many times now, and just between 
        you and me, there's really no big surprises here, so...make-up sex is 
        all that I have left.

I'm sure you'll have another fight, George. <Stamps 
        on George's foot and closes the door.> (To Billy) Hold that thought!

So, listen to this. But don't tell anyone - Jerry Seinfeld? He 
        got a woman's number off an AIDS walk list.
He got her number off an AIDS walk list?
He what?
How'd you find out?
A friend of a friend of a friend of Susan's.
George!
Pardon?
Nothing. Listen, I'm sorry, I just -
It's o.k.! There's nothing to be sorry about. I don't mind.
You don't mind that I got your number off the AIDS walk list?

No, not at all. No problem. <Jerry looks at Lena suspiciously. 
        Lena leaves with all of Kramer's poker buddies, who are filing out of 
        Kramer's apartment.>

Ah, you're lucky you're walkin' out of here with a pair of pants 
        on!
You went all night?
Jerry, ah? Breakfast on me, huh?

Kramer, are you out of your mind? You got the AIDS walk in like, 
        three hours! You're never gonna make it!
AIDS walk! That's a cake walk. <George enters.> Hey!
So, George, guess what? Lena found out how I got her number.
Really? How'd she do that?
A friend of a friend of Susan's.
My Susan?
Why'd you tell her?!

Because, Jerry, it's a couple rule! We have to tell each other 
        everything!
Well you know what this means, don't you?
What?
You're cut off, you're out of the loop!
You're cutting me off? No, no, no Jerry, don't cut me off!
You leave me no choice! You're the media now as far as I'm concerned!
C'mon Jerry, please! It won't happen again.

If you were in the mafia, would you tell her every time you killed 
        someone?
Hey, a "hit" is a totally different story.
I don't know, George.
So, Lena was upset, huh?
You know what? That was the amazing thing.
What, it didn't bother her?

No, she said it was fine. There's something very strange about 
        this girl.
What?
She's too good.
Too good...

I mean, she's giving and caring and genuinely concerned about 
        the welfare of others - I can't be with someone like that!
I see what you mean.

I mean, I admire the hell out of her. You can't have sex with 
        someone you admire.
Where's the depravity?

No depravity! I mean, I look at her, I can't imagine she even 
        has sex.
On the other hand...
What?
Thanks again for last night!
Hey, I didn't even use one.
I thought you said it was imminent.

Yeah, it was, but then I just couldn't decide if he was really 
        sponge-worthy.
Sponge-worthy?
Yeah, Jerry, I have to conserve these sponges.
But you like this guy, isn't that what the sponges are for?

Yes, yes - before they went off the market. I mean, now I've 
        got to re-evaluate my whole screening process. I can't afford to waste 
        any of 'em.
You know, you're nuts with these sponges. George is gettin' frustrated!
Uh, Cosmo Kramer?
Uh...o.k., you're checked in. Here's your AIDS ribbon.
Uh, no thanks.
You don't want to wear an AIDS ribbon?
No.
But you have to wear an AIDS ribbon.
I have to?
Yes.
See, that's why I don't want to.
But everyone wears the ribbon. You must wear the ribbon!
You know what you are? You're a ribbon bully. <Walks away.>
Hey you! Come back here! Come back here and put this on!

Elaine and her sponges...she's got like, a war chest full of 
        them.
Well, I don't see why you just can't use condoms.

Oh, no, no...condoms are for single men. The day that we got 
        engaged, I said goodbye to the condom forever.
Just once...for the make-up sex.

Make-up sex? You have to have that right after the fight, we're 
        way past that.
Come on, just once?
No, no...I hate the condom.
Why?
I can never get the package open in time.
Well, you just tear it open.

It's not that easy. It's like "Beat The Clock," there's 
        a lot of pressure there.
Hey, where's your ribbon?
Oh, I don't wear the ribbon.
Oh, you don't wear the ribbon? Aren't you against AIDS?

Yeah, I'm against AIDS. I mean, I'm walking, aren't I? I just 
        don't wear the ribbon.
Who do you think you are?
Put the ribbon on!

Hey, Cedric! Bob! This guy won't wear a ribbon! <Cedric 
        and Bob turn around and glare at Kramer.>
Who? Who does not want to wear the ribbon? <Kramer is frightened.>
So, you think you're sponge-worthy?
Yes, I think I'm sponge-worthy. I think I'm very sponge-worthy.
Run down your case for me again...?

Well, we've gone out several times, we obviously have a good rapport. 
        I own a very profitable electronics distributing firm. I eat well. I exercise. 
        Blood tests - immaculate. And if I can speak frankly, I'm actually quite 
        good at it.
You going to do something about your sideburns?
Yeah, I told you...I'm going to trim my sideburns.
And the bathroom in your apartment?
Cleaned it this morning.
The sink, the tub, everything got cleaned?
Everything, yeah. It's spotless.
Alright, let's go. <They head for the bedroom.>
Hi.

Hi! Hey, look at this - I just got a citation in the mail for my 
        work with shut-ins.

Oh, the shut-ins, that's nice. You know, they're a very eccentric 
        group. Because they're shut in. Of course, they're not locked in, they're 
        free to go at anytime.

Oh, by the way, I checked at the soup kitchen - they do have cream 
        soups.

Hey, that's dynamite. You know, Lena, I wanted to talk to you 
        about something...you know, because you're such a good person -

Oh, hang onto that thought - I'm rinsing a sweater, I left the 
        water running. <Goes into the bathroom.> Hey, Jerry, can you get 
        me a towel out of my bedroom closet?

Oh, o.k. <Goes to the closet for the towel and finds dozens 
        of boxes of Today sponges.>

Oh my god! Look what's goin' on here! She is depraved! 
        <Grabs a towel and brings it to Lena.> There you are.
Thanks. So, you were saying...?
What? Nothing.
No, you said I was a good person...
Oh...
You seem like you want to tell me something.
Tell you something...I do.
What is it, Jerry? You can tell me anything.
Oh, uh...you see these jeans I'm wearing?
Yeah.

I change the 32 waist on the label to a 31 on all my jeans. So, 
        you know. That's it. <Lena is puzzled.>
Come on, George, just tear it open.
I'm trying, dammit.
Tear it.

I tried to tear it from the side, you can't get a good grip here. 
        You gotta do it like a bag of chips.
Here give it to me.
Would you wait a second? Just wait? <They fight over it.>
Give it to me. <She rips it open.> Come on. Come on!
It's too late.
So! What's it going to be? Are you going to wear the ribbon?
No! Never.

But I am wearing the ribbon. He is wearing the ribbon. We are all 
        wearing the ribbon! So why aren't you going to wear the ribbon!?

This is America! I don't have to wear anything I don't want to 
        wear!
What are we gonna do with him?
I guess we are just going to have to teach him to wear the ribbon!
It completely turned her off.

Well, I can see that. What do you have to do that for? Who cares 
        about your pants size?
I don't wanna be a 32.
I'd kill to be a 32.
She said I wasn't sponge-worthy. Wouldn't waste a sponge on me!

That condom killed me. Why do they have to make the wrappers 
        on those things so hard to open?
It's probably so the woman has one last chance to change her mind.

You never run out, do you? <Jerry smiles.> Where's Kramer? 
        Everything's finished here.

Oh, I told him he'd never make it. He was up all night! Oh my 
        god...Kramer?

Look at you. I told you. Up all night playing poker. Come on. 
        <Jerry and George are about to leave. George turn's back and looks 
        at Kramer.>
Hey, where's you AIDS ribbon?
Good morning.
How'd you sleep?
Great. You?
Fine, fine. Everything o.k.?
Yep.
No regrets?
Nope. <Billy leans in to kiss her.> What are you doing?
What do you mean?
Oh...I don't think so.
Why not? I thought you said everything was fine.

I wish I could help you, but I can't afford two of 'em. <Pats 
        Billy on the shoulder and gets out of bed.>

(Sarcastic) Yeah, and it was rammed by the 
              Cat Stevens.

(Like a teacher) The Andrea Doria collided 
              with the Stockholm in dense fog 21 miles off the coast of Nantucket. 
              (Makes a clicking sound with his
How do you know?

it's in my book - "Astonishing Tales 
              of the Sea" 51 people died.
51 people?!
That's it?! I thought it was, like, a thousand!
There were 1,650 survivors.

That's no tragedy! How many people do you 
              lose on a normal cruse? 30? 40?! Kramer, can I take a look at that 
              book? (Starts walking tward the door.

Oh yeah. I also got "Astounding Bear 
              Attacks"

Hey, uh, before you go, did you talk to Newman 
              about getting that mail outta there?

Yeah, oh, yeah. Yeah, he's not gonna do it. 
              (Leaves)
Newman's apartment]
Newman?
(Eyes glued to the TV) I guess.

Listen, I want you to get the mail outta my 
              storage unit.
Sometimes we don't get what we want.
(Confused) What are you talking about?
I didn't get my transfer.
"Transfer"?

To Hawaii. The most sought-after postal route 
              of them all. The air is so dewy-sweet you don't even have to like 
              the stamps.. But it's not to be - So, I'm
You quit the post office?

Kind of. I'm still collecting checks, I'm 
              just not delivering mail.
Well, get it out of my storage. It's illegal.

And yet, it's perfectly legal to take a man's 
              soul and crush it out like a stale Pall Mall.
(Cheerfully) Well, a law's a law. (Leaves)
Central Park]

Ok, hold on there.. That's a nasty cough you 
              got there, huh?
What cough?
Restaurant]

I love shrimp! (Waves her knife around as 
              she's talking) I'm a shrimp eater. You put shrimp infront of me, 
              (Waves her knife along with her hand gestures.

No, it's okay. I'm.. still just a little bit 
              jumpy.

(Leans in close) Between you and me, what 
              happened there with the stabbing?
Just.. one of those things, you know.

What? Was she just so crazy in love with you 
              that she just couldn't take it anymore? Or..?
I don't know. Could be.
Alan?!
Carol?

(Gets up, pointing after Carol) Was that the 
              one?! Was that the one who stabbed you?!
(Between screams) No, that was a different girl.
Coffee shop]
There was another crazed ex-girlfriend?

Right, so, I called my friend, you know - 
              the one who set us up - I found out, he's a bad-breaker-upper.
Mmm.. Bad how?

(Fast) Well, you know when you break up, how 
              you say things you don't mean? Well, he says the mean things you 
              don't mean, but he means them.
(Nods) I follow. So what are you gonna do?

Dump him. I can't be with someone who doesn't 
              break up nicely. I mean, to me, that's one of the most important 
              parts of a relationship.
(Agreeing) What's more important?
NYC Street]
(Between coughs) Hey.
What's with the dog?

(Petting Smuckers) Yeah, this is Smuckers. 
              I borrowed him. (Starts coughing)
Oh..

(Pointing at the dog) Yeah, we share the same 
              affliction, so I'm gonna have a vet check us out.
A vet?

Oh, I'll take a vet over an M.D. any day. 
              They gotta be able to cure a (Snaps his fingers in rhythm with his 
              words) lizard, a chicken, a pig, a frog (Stops

So, if I may jump ahead - you're gonna take 
              dog medicine?

(Smiling) You bet we are! Huh, Smuckers? (Smuckers 
              coughs. They turn to leave) I'll see ya.
George's apartment building]

Ahoy! Mr. Eldridge. I understand you were 
              on the Andrea Doria.
Yes, it was a terrifying ordeal.

I tell ya, I hear people really stuff themselves 
              on those cruise ships. (Laughs) The buffet, that's the real ordeal, 
              huh, Clarence? (Laughs)
(Defensively) We had to abandon ship.
Well, all vacations have to end eventually.
The boat sank.

(Holding up Kramer's book) According to this, 
              it took.. 10 hours. It eased into the water like an old man into 
              a nice warm bath - no offence. (Pause) So,

Is that what this is all about?! I don't 
              think I like you. (Enters his apartment, and slams the door behind 
              him)

(Yelling out) It's my apartment, Eldridge! 
              The Stalkholm may not have sunk ya, but I will! Ha, ha, ha!
Vet's office]
What are the symptoms?

Well, uh.. it hurts when he swallows. Expecially 
              when he drinks orange juice. (Vet gives him a look) I mean, uh.. 
              dog food.. juice. (Adding) What's

Yeah, well, uh - we've been seeing a lot of this 
              lately. Been drinking from the toilet?
(Offended) What? No. That's disgusting..
Coffee shop]
So that's it? We're, uh, we're breakin' up?

(Confused by his sudden change-of-heart) What? 
              Break-up? We went out on one date.

(Fast) Ok, yeah, sure, fine, right. Whatever 
              you say.

(Shows no sign that she cares) Alright, good. 
              Good.

Ok, then, well, So.. see ya around.. big head. 
              (Gets up to leave)
Pardon?

You got a big head. It's too big for your body. 
              (Walks for the door)

(Laughing out loud) That's it?! (Laughs again) 
              That's the best you got?! (Laughs loudly as Alan exits)
Jerry's apartment]

So, he's keeping the apartment. He doesn't 
              deserve it, though! Even if he did suffer, that was, like, 40 years 
              ago! What has he been doing lately?! I've

You know, if this tenant board is so impressed 
              with suffering, maybe you should tell them the "Astonishing 
              Tales of Costanza".
(Interested) I should!

I mean, your body of work in this field is 
              unparalleled.

I could go bumper to bumper with any one else 
              on this planet!
You're the man!
Jerry!

I'm with people, I'll be with you in a moment. 
              (Slams the door on Newman's face. Then tries to delay talking to 
              Newman by keeping the conversation with

Nah, I guess I should really get moving on 
              this, huh? I'm gonna go. (Opens the door, letting Newman in. Leaves)
(Angered) Hello.. Newman.
(Urgent) I need that mail, where is it?!
What's the difference?

The guy who had the Hawaii transfer got busted 
              for hoarding Victoria Secret catalogues. I gotta deliver that mail!
Well, go ahead. There's 8 bags of it.

Blast! There's no way I can handle 8 in addition 
              to my ususal load of one! I'll never get to Hawaii! (Moves over 
              to Jerry's couch, depressed) I'll be
You're giving up that easy?
I usually do. (Gets up to leave) See ya.

(Stopping him) No, wait a minute, Newman! You 
              can't let this dream die. You moving away is my dream too!
(Intrigued) What are you proposing?

(Fast) Whatever it takes, for as long as it 
              takes me, where ever it takes me as long as it takes you away from 
              me!
An alliance?

(Confirming) An alliance. (They both shake 
              hands and laugh evily) Now get the hell outta here. (Newman leaves)
Jerry's apartment]

Hawaii? That's why you're helping Newman with 
              the mail?

(Like an Army general) Elaine, Newman is my 
              sworn enemy. And he lives down the hall from my home - my home, 
              Elaine! Where I sleep, where I come to

"Big head" (Scoffs) That's almost 
              a compliment.

(Agreeing) It's one of the nicest things anyone's 
              ever said to me.
Hello?
(On the other line) Hey.
Hey, George.
Yeah, listen, I can't make it later.
You can't make it?

Yeah, the tenant association has decided to 
              hear my side of the story. So, uh, I gotta kinda get ready. I'll 
              see ya.
Alright. (Hangs up)
Is he not gonna go to the coffee shop?
(Saddened) Doesn't look like it's gonna happen.

(Gives a "That's a shame" face) 
              Alright, well, I'll see ya. (Opens the door to exit. Kramer enters 
              coughing. Elaine does her best to dodge out of the way of

Kramer, aren't you taking any medication for 
              that?

Yeah, yeah. (Pulls a bottle out of his pocket) 
              I got some pilss. They taste terrible.
(Takes the bottle from him) Just swallow 'em.

(Gestures to his throat) No, my throat's too 
              tender.

Alright, sit down, sit down. (Grabs a pill 
              from the bottle, and starts advancing tward Kramer - like an owner 
              with his dog)
I don't want to!
C'mon. Just sit down!
(Squirming) Jerry! What?!
Sit down! Sit down!
(Struggling) Hey!

Lean your head back. Open your mouth! (Grabs 
              Kramer's head) Open your mouth! Open it! Open it!

(Reads the pill bottle) What kind of pills 
              are these, anyways?! "For Smuckers"? "May cause panting 
              and loss of fur"? (Turns to Kramer) These are dog
Whe have the same symptoms.
But, he's a dog! You need to see a real doctor.
No, no. No doctors.

Alright.. (Heads for the door, grabbing his 
              coat)
Where are you going?

I'm taking the car. I gotta run some errands. 
              You want to go?
I don't know..

(Opens the door) C'mon, you wanna go for a 
              ride? (Starts jiggling his keys - as if he's calling out for a dog) 
              Huh? C'mon! C'mon!
Taxi cab]
Lady, could you move your head a little bit?
What?

Your head. I can't see out the back. (Elaine 
              slumps down in her seat) Little more.. (Elaine slumps lower) ..Little 
              more. (Slides down until just her eyes and
Jerry's car]

I don't see any tissues back her.. (Looks 
              out the windows) Wait a minute!.. (Jerry looks like he's trying 
              to keep something from Kramer) This isn't the
Coffee shop]

So, uh, Mom, Dad, I was hoping that you could 
              help me to remember my childhood a little clearly..

I feel a draft. (Grabs the bread basket and 
              her drink) Let's change tables.
Get outta here! We have a booth.
Frank, I'm cold!
Order a hot dish.

Why can't we sit over there? (Points to a 
              table)
(Yelling) That's not a booth!

(Trying to match Frank's loudness) So, who 
              says we have to sit in a booth?!

(Loud shouting) I didn't take the subway all 
              the way to New York to sit at a table like that! (Gestures to the 
              table)

(Nagging yell) Well, I didn't take the subway 
              to be in a drafty restaurant!
(Pleading for them to stop) Mom.. dad.

Now, George, what do you want to know about 
              your childhood?

(Fed up with his parents) Actually, I think 
              I'm pretty clear on it.
(Looks up) Where's that breeze coming from?
NYC Street]
Kramer, outta the car. Out, now!
No, Jerry!

Alright, that's it.. (Grabs Kramer, trying 
              to pull him out of the car)
No! Don't!

Hey, hey! Get back over here! Kramer! Get over 
              here! You are bad! Bad neighbor! Kramer!
Tenant board room]

Just then, a rescue ship emerged from the 
              fog and saved us. It was.. (Stops, then gives George a look. George 
              stops knocking on the walls) It was the

(Touched) Thank you Mr. Eldridge. The tenant 
              board will now hear Mr. Costanza's testimony.
Newman's apartment]

Newman, how'd it go? Did you get it all delivered? 
              (Sees the pac) What happened?
Kramer bit me!
Bit you?!

We had an arguement about me going to Hawaii, 
              and he locked onto my ankle like it was a soup bone. I'm hubbled! 
              I don't think I can do my route -
(Bravely) Well, what if I deliver it?

You?! (Laughs hysterically) You can't deliver 
              mail!
Well, why not?

(Thinks for a moment) I guess you're right. 
              It's just walking around putting it into boxes..
What am I gonna wear?

I could give you my uniform from my rookie 
              year.
(Excited) I can't believe I'm gonna be a mailman!
(Hands him some mail) There you go. Merry Chirstmas!
Mail on Sunday?

(Shrugs) Oops. (Continues walking along the 
              route, whistling. Hands a newspaper to a homeless bum on the street, 
              then keeps walking)
Tenant board room]

I was handcuffed to the bed.. In my underwear, 
              (Sighs) where I remained.. (Scene cuts to another story) She was 
              attractive.. She was, also, infact, a
Newman's apartment]

Hey, I've been trying to jam stuff in the box, 
              like you told me, but sometimes it says, like, "Photographs 
              - Do not bend".

"Do not bend". (Laughs evilly) Just 
              crease, crumple, cram.. you'll do fine. (Phone rings. Newman answers 
              it) Hello?.. This is he. I don't understand..
What?

That was the Vice President of the post office. 
              I didn't get the transfer.. They knew it wasn't me doing my route!
How did they know?!

(Stands up) Too many people go their mail! 
              Close to 80%. No body from the post office has ever cracked the 
              50% barrier! It's like the 3-minute mile!
(Pleading) I tried my best!

Exactly. You're a disgrace to the uniform. 
              (Newman takes off Jerry's mailman hat. Jerry turns his head in shame. 
              Newman then tears the post office
You know, this is your coat.
(Realizing) Damn!
Central park]

He flew right into your head. Like he couldn't 
              avoid it.
(Rubbing her head to relieve the pain) Really?

Never seen that before. Bird into a woman's 
              head..
Coffee shop]

It's not contest. The guy had nothing! The 
              ship went down, he got into a life boat, I mean, come on.

Boy, he didn't know what he was up against. 
              (George laughs) So, when do you move into the apartment?
They're making their decision today.
What's the matter with you?

Nothing.. Except that a bird ran into my giant 
              freak-head. (Sits down)
What giant freak-head?

(Annoyed, near tears) The one that sits atop 
              my disproportunately puny body.. I'm a walking candy apple!

So, it's actually gotten to you? You're playing 
              right into his hands!

(Realizing) What? Yeah.. you're right!.. All 
              I have to do is call him up, and sit with him, and show him that 
              it doesn't bother me. You know, laugh it off.. or
(Casually, sarcastic) Either way.
(Getting up to leave) Alright.
Restaurant]
I want to apologize for..
(Shrugging it off) Oh, please.
So you have a big head.
(Casually playing along) So what?
It goes well with that bump in your nose.
(Suddenly angry) What?!

Please! Get help! There's a crazy big-headed 
              woman beating up some guy! Tell the police "The Old Mill Restaurant". 
              Hurry!
Boy, that's some cough you got there.

No, I think he's trying to tell us something. 
              What is it? (Between coughs, Kramer manages to say the word "trouble") 
              Trouble?! Trouble? Where? Where's
George's apartment building]
Excuse me, uh, what are you doing in there?

I'm moving in. Alan Mercer. New neighbor. (They 
              shake hands)

What? Elaine's big-head guy? They have you 
              the apartment?!
Yeah.

Why?! Because you were stabbed, and.. got 
              coffee thrown in your face, and.. uh.. (Points to Alan's bandaged 
              forehead)
Oh, fork in the forehead.
That's why they gave you the apartment?
No, I just gave the super 50 bucks.

Wait a minute, that is my apartment. I earned 
              it with 34 years of misery!

Tough luck, chinless. (Goes into his new apartment, 
              and slams the door on George)

Barney Martin (Morty)
        Liz Sheridan (Helen)
        John Michael Higgins (Kurt)
        Miguel Sandoval (Marcelino)
        Andrea Bendewald (Celia)
        Kathryn Joosten (Betsy)
        Paul Perri (Detective #1)
        Al White (Detective #2)
        Ray Proscia (Prison guard)
Jerry and Elaine are waiting on the street for George.

So what happened to you yesterday? We were supposed to go to the 
        auto show, I waited for you, you never came.
I'm sorry, I got really busy. How long did you wait?
Five minutes.
Five minutes? That's it?
What's the difference? You never showed up.

I could've! I mean, last week we waited for that friend of Kramer's 
        for like, forty minutes.
Well, we barely knew the guy.
So, the longer you know someone, the shorter you wait for 'em.
That's the way it works.
When did you tell George to be here?
I told him to meet us here in ten minutes. How long has it been?
About five.
That's enough. <They leave. George comes around the corner.>
Early! Alright! <shivers.> Cold.
So, I noticed you bounced a check at the bodega.
How did you know about that?

Because Marcelino, he taped it up on his cash register with all 
        the other bad checks.
He can't do that.

It's the only way you'll learn. (Tastes his eggs.) 
        Aw, these eggs are disgusting. This chicken should be ashamed of himself.
Fantastic day! Fantastic!
What happened?

Well, first, I'm brushing my teeth and this piece of apple-skin, 
        that must have been lodged in there for days, comes loose.
Fantastic.
Then, I'm at The Foundation...
You're still doing that?
Sometimes, once in a while.
When you feel guilty.

No, occasionally I'll forget to let the machine pick up. Anyway, 
        they made this large donation to a women's prison, and I get to go down 
        there and check it out.
That's caged heat.
Yeah-hah!
What are you gonna do there?

Nothing really, you know...just stroll around the cell blocks, 
        maybe take in a shower fight. (chuckles.) Hey, you know you got a bounced 
        check hanging up in the little market over on Columbus?
Yes, I know, I know.

I noticed you chose the "clowns with balloons" check 
        design.
It was a mistake, the bank sent me the wrong ones.

Hey! Look who's here! Hey Kurt, this is Jerry, and George, and 
        Kramer.
Hey, Kurt. Taste these eggs.
Uh, no - I only eat cage-free, farm-fresh.

Yes! These are sweatshop eggs. <Kramer gets up to leave by 
        climbing over the back of the booth. He loses it and falls on the floor, 
        then regains his composure and walks out with his napkin still tucked 
        in his collar.>

I gotta call the office. Honey, would you order for 
        me?
I'm a "honey." He's pretty great, huh?
Is he from the future?
No, he just shaves his head. I think it's pretty gutsy.

Listen, sweetheart, let me tell you a little something about 
        guts. <Points to his head.> This is guts.
What? Clinging to some scraps?

These are not "scraps." These are historic remains 
        of a once great society of hair.

Oh, did you guys stop at the bodega today? Some moron bounced 
        a clown check!

character:
New scene in the bodega, starts with a shot of Marcelino's cash register 
        with Jerry's clown check attached under a sign that reads "checks 
        no longer accepted from

line: Again, I'm really sorry about the check, Marcelino.
People seem to like the clowns.

Look, let me just give you the forty, plus 
        another twenty for your trouble.
'Kay.
Aren't you going to take the check down?
Sorry, no. It's store policy.
But it's your bodega.
Even I am not above the policy.
Those are our tennis courts.

Tennis courts? What about the yard? Where do they have the gang 
        fights?

There's no fights here, Mr. Costanza. This is a minimum security 
        facility.
Hmm. What about a hole? You ever put anybody in "the box"?
No.
This prison stinks.

And finally, the library, which has just been refurbished thanks 
        to your generous donation. This is Celia Morgan, our librarian.
Nice to meet you.
I'll be in my office if you need me.
Thanks, Warden.
Betsy.
Betsy.
So, are you the head of the foundation?

Well, let's just say it wouldn't exist without me. <Notices 
        another person in the library dressed the same as Celia.> So uh, you 
        two shop at the same store?
No, it's standard issue.
Oh my God...you're in jail? <Celia nods.> That is so cool!
You asked her out?
Well...not "out." She's in prison.
How could you ask her out?
Why not?

I remember when you wouldn't date that girl who lived in Queens 
        because you didn't want to go over the bridge!
That was different!
I'll say.

Jerry, I like being with her. Plus, I know where she is all the 
        time. I have relatively no competition. And you know how you live in fear 
        of the pop-in?
The pop-in.

Yeah, no pop-in, no "in the neighborhood," no "I 
        saw your light was on." And the best part is, if things go really 
        well...
Conjugal visit?
Don't jinx it!
Hey. What's up?
George is dating a convict.
Oh? What's she in for?
Embezzlement.

Sounds like a nice girl. Hey Jerry, is it all right 
        if I put some stuff in your fridge? 'Cause mine's full.
Yeah, sure. You don't even have a fridge, do you?

Well, not here. <Goes into the hallway, comes back in with 
        a huge bag of chicken feed.>
Kramer, wait a minute, what the hell is that?
Well, it's chicken feed. <Slams the bag into Jerry's fridge.>
I sense something is afoot.
Yeah, I bought a chicken.
Allow me. Why?
Cage-free, farm-fresh eggs.
Allow me. What are you, an idiot?

Hold it, hold it, I got it. Catch. <Tosses his wallet to Elaine, 
        she pays the delivery guy.>

character: ELAINE (looking at Kurt's driver's licence photo)
line:
Hey, driver's licence. 
        Oh...my God.
What?
Your hair. It's so thick and lustrous. I mean, it...it was.

Well, it still is. I shave my head for my swim team. I just liked 
        the way it looked, so I kept it.

Are you saying that I could be dating this hair? With you under 
        it? <Kurt shrugs.>
Is that your "chicken" making all that noise?
Oh, Jerry loves the morning.
Who?
Little Jerry Seinfeld. I named my chicken after you.
Thanks, that's very sweet, but that is not a chicken.
Of course it is. I picked it out myself.
Well, you picked out a rooster.
Well, that would explain Little Jerry's poor egg production.
This was fun.
Yeah. I had a great time.
Five minutes, Mr. Costanza.
The whole hour just flew by. <Begins cleaning up the table.>
I'll get that.

Oh, thanks, Bobby. (To Celia) Well, I guess I'll see you in four 
        days.

Go out and have a ball with the guys. I'll be waiting right here 
        for you.
Of course you will. You're the best.
Hello?

Jerry? Leo told us he saw your bounced 
        check. Are you having money problems?
I'm not having money problems.

Enough with the comedy! You're very clever, you should look into 
        advertising.
He never even called Ed Roydlick. They were looking for someone!
I'm not calling Ed Roydlick. I'm doing fine! <George enters.>
That's it. I'm going to send you fifty dollars.
You are NOT sending me fifty dollars!
We're sending you fifty dollars! Morty, get me an envelope.

I swear to God, if you send me fifty dollars, you are 
        gonna be so sorry!
I don't see envelopes!

They're right in front of you! Oh, for heaven's sakes... <She 
        puts the phone down on the couch and goes to help Morty.>
Ma! Ma! MA! <Hangs up the phone in disgust.>
How're the folks?
Good.
So? Movie tonight?
I thought you were going out with Celia.
I did. I'm back. I love this relationship, I feel so liberated!
Having her in jail.

The only thing that bothers me is that I'm just coming up with 
        this now.
Yeah, dating a convicted felon. I don't know how you missed it.

Here. <Shows Kurt's driver's licence to Jerry.> Take a 
        look at that.
Huh. Kurt's an organ donor.

No! He's not bald. Look! He's got a full head of hair. <George 
        overhears and stands up, concerned.>
So he just shaves his head for no reason?
That's like using a wheelchair for the fun of it!

And he's growing it in just for me. (Happily) It's mine. It's 
        all mine.
It's just hair.
It's not just hair! Look! <Shows Kurt's licence to Jerry again.>
It's brown.
It's chestnut with auburn highlights!
So?

You're not around women. You don't know how important a man's 
        hair is. <They both look at George, who is reading a newspaper and 
        struggling to keep his composure.> I'm sorry, George, but it's true.
I knew it.
Hey, Kramer. Nice rooster. What's his name?
Well, this is Little Jerry Seinfeld.
Little Jerry Seinfeld. Does he bounce checks? (laughs)
Look, can't you take Jerry's check down?
Sorry Kramer, can't help you.
I like the way he handles himself.

Oh, it's coming in already! Wow, you have some very nice little 
        seedlings here. Huh...
What?
Well, it doesn't seem to be coming in so good over here. Or here.
What do you mean? <Goes into the bedroom to look in the mirror.>

Well, I don't know...how long have you been shaving your head 
        for?
About three years.
Huh.
Oh my God! <Steps into the doorway> I'm going bald!
George! I'm so glad to see you!

Hey, I brought you some cigarettes. You buy yourself something 
        nice.
Good news - I'm up for parole.
Parole! <Feigning joy> That's dynamite!
So Marcelino's going to take down the check?
Well, it comes down if Little Jerry Seinfeld wins the cockfight.
Great! <realizing> What?
Well, Marcelino, he has cockfights in the back of his store.
Ah ha...
So, he says if Little Jerry Seinfeld wins, the check comes down.
Kramer, cockfighting is illegal.
Only in The United States.
It's inhumane!
No, Jerry, it's not what you think it is.
It's two roosters peckin' at each other!
What?
Yeah!

Well, I thought they wore gloves and helmets, you know, like 
        "American Gladiators."
No Kramer, Little Jerry could get hurt.
Well, I left him with Marcelino!
My Little Jerry! <Runs out.>
Hey, did you get Little Jerry, is he O.K.?
Well, he's more than O.K., he won!
You let him fight?

I couldn't get there in time to stop it, but you should have 
        seen Little Jerry, Jerry! Flappin' his wings and struttin' his stuff! 
        He was peckin' and weavin' and bobbin' and talkin' trash! He didn't even 
        have to touch him! The other rooster ran out of the ring. The whole fight 
        lasted two seconds.
How long do they usually last?

Five seconds. And Marcelino says he's taking your check down 
        today.
Great!
Hey.
Celia's up for parole.
Hey, Little Jerry won his cockfight.
What?
Who?
I'm too tired.

O.K., listen, I want you to come by later, alright? 
        'Cause we're having a victory party for Little Jerry.
Alright. <Kramer leaves.>
It's over, Jerry. She's gettin' out.
Ah, I'm so sorry.

She's been locked up for two years. She's gonna want to make 
        up for lost time. Dinners. Movies. <Rubs his forehead.> Talking...
In other words, a normal relationship.

And that's no good. I've tried it straight, Jerry. We've all 
        seen the results. For me, sick is the only way to go.
Well, she'll still be an ex-con.
It's not the same.

Hey, if you two are meant to be together...I'm sure the cops'll 
        pick her up on something.
Kurt? What's with the sweats? Aren't we going out?
I don't care.
You, uh...got a big stain on your shirt.
Yeah...meatball...fell out of my sandwich.
You already ate?
It's from yesterday.
Jerry! You missed a hell of a cockfight last night.
Then what is my check still doing up? We had a deal!
Now we have a new deal.
New deal?
When Little Jerry Seinfeld is mine, the check will be yours.
This is outrageous! (To Marcelino) Pack of Juicy Fruit.

character: MARCELINO (puts the gum on the counter)
line: 85 cents.
85 cents? That is outrageous!
Kramer, Marcelino wants us to sell him Little Jerry Seinfeld.
Well, that's out of the question.
But Kramer, cockfighting is an illegal and immoral activity.
Yeah, if you got a loser. But Little Jerry was born to cockfight!

No, no more cockfighting. Let's just sell him to Marcelino the 
        cockfighter and be done with it!
You know, I think you're jealous.
Of what?

character: KRAMER (points at Jerry like he's found him out)
line:
Yah, yah! You see in 
        Little Jerry Seinfeld the unlimited future you once had. Now, just because 
        Jerry Seinfeld is a has-been, don't make Little Jerry Seinfeld a never-was!
Kramer, give me that rooster!

Never! You hate him because he's doing more with your name than 
        you ever will! Yah-yah! <Kramer leaves.>

George, Celia has listed you as a character reference. Whatever 
        you can tell us would certainly be helpful in her getting paroled.

Well, anything I can do to help, um...she's a wonderful girl. 
        Very smart. Very...crafty.
Does she have any plans after she's released?

Plans. Schemes. She keeps talking about getting back together 
        with her old friends - "the gang," as she likes to call them, 
        you know. Yeah, they're hatching something, you can count on that.
Jerry! Tonight's fight-night. Where's my rooster?
Kramer won't sell.

Well, tell you what I'm gonna do. I'm gonna take down your 
        check anyway.
Well, thank you, Marcelino.

Well, perhaps someday you will do me a favor. And that day 
        is today. Little Jerry Seinfeld must go down in the third round of tomorrow's 
        main event.
You want Little Jerry to take a dive?
Shhh, not so loud.
First of all, I don't think you can make a rooster take a dive.
Can, too!

Second of all, Jerry Seinfeld - big or little - doesn't go down 
        for anyone, anywhere, at anytime! Now I'd appreciate it if you please 
        leave.
Big Jerry is making a big mistake, Jerry.

We'll see about that. <Runs to the window and shouts up to 
        Kramer, who's on the roof.> Kramer, I'm comin' up! We got a cockfight 
        to win!
O.K.!
Elaine said you would be the best person I could talk to.

character: GEORGE (examining Kurt's head with a lamp)
line:
Yep. Classic horseshoe pattern. 
        I've seen a lot of this.
Oh, God.
No, no, Kurt - wrong attitude. You should be happy now.
Happy? Why should I be happy?

You've still got pretty good coverage. Once the enemy advances 
        beyond this perimeter - <points at Kurt's head with a pen> - then 
        you won't be Kurt anymore.
Who will I be?
How long do I have?
14 months. Maybe 10.
Is there anything I can do?

Yes. Live, dammit. Live! Every precious moment as if this was 
        the last year of your life. Because in many ways...it is. <There's 
        a knock at the door.> Excuse me.
Celia? What are you doing here?
Well, I didn't get my parole, so I busted out.
And you just decided to pop in...!
Kurt!

Elaine...<holds out a wedding ring> Will you marry me? <Elaine 
        is shocked.>
Oh, yeah. He's lookin' good, huh Jerry?

Yeah. Alright, I think that's enough for today. <Kramer picks 
        up Little Jerry and takes him to the sink.> Little Jerry is lean, mean, 
        peckin' machine! <Kramer starts filling a pot with water.> What 
        are you doing with that?

I'm just gonna heat this up. Make a little hot-tub for Little 
        Jerry.
Hey, Kramer...?

Be careful. <George enters.> Hey, guess what! Little Jerry 
        ran from here to Newman's in under thirty seconds!
Is that good?
I don't know. Where have you been?

Celia broke out of prison. I'm sitting in my home, she shows 
        up at the door!
Oh my God! The break-out/pop-in!

Yeah. Hey Jerry, listen to this. I discovered something even 
        better than conjugal visit sex. Fugitive sex! Now, it's like everytime 
        -

George, this is a little too much for me - escaped 
        convicts, fugitive sex...I got a cockfight to focus on. <Jerry leaves.>

Hey Kurt, slow down! I just can't marry you, whim-bam-boom! I 
        mean, I need some "fiance-time," I need some "make-my-girlfriends-jealous" 
        time...
Plus, you want to get to know me.
Yeah, yeah, that too.
Well, how much time?
I don't know...a year?
No, no, no...it has to be now.
Could I see the ring again?
So, you're actually considering it?

Well, it'll be a couple of years before he's completely bald. 
        Those'll be good times.
Marriage is a big step, Elaine. Your life'll totally change.

Jerry, it's three-thirty in the morning. I'm at a cockfight. 
        What am I clinging to? <George comes over.>
Hey, sorry I'm late.
Where's Celia?

She didn't want to come, she's not really into sports. <Kramer 
        comes over with Little Jerry.>
Hey, how's he doin'?

He's got a big sweat going. <Takes an envelope out of his 
        pocket.> Oh, this came for you express-mail. It's from your parents.
Fifty dollars. I don't believe this!

There's Marcelino. <Marcelino enters the ring holding a huge 
        white rooster.>
Look at the size of his bird!
That looks like a dog with a glove on his head.

Hi, is George back from the cockfight yet? You know, I gotta thank 
        him, he changed my life.
No, it must have been a good fight, he's not back yet.
Ah, damn.

Sorry to bother you, Mr. Costanza. Well, well, 
        well. Look who's here.
Aw, man!

Mr. Costanza, you're under arrest for aiding 
        and abetting a known fugitive.
I'm not George Costanza.

Save it. We know you're bald. We know it's you. Let's go! 
        <They escort Kurt and Celia out.>

character: ELAINE (to a woman at the fight)
line:
Muchos gracias. <Turns back to Jerry 
        and Kramer.> O.K., I got the whole scoop. Marcelino flew the bird in 
        from Ecuador. He's 68 and 0!
He's a ringer!

Where's the tamale guy? <The bell rings, and the cockfight 
        begins.>

Little Jerry's going to get his clock cleaned. I gotta get him 
        outta there.
Little Jerry!
Kramer!
Stop the fight!
Tamale!
Why did you get into a fist fight with the cop? You were innocent!

They thought I was George. I'm not that bald. I have too little 
        time left to take that kind of crap, so I slugged him.
So, how long are you gonna be in here for?
Well, my lawyer says 14 months, but with good behavior, maybe...10?
So, 10 to 14 months.
Yeah.

So, they have this clock now, where you punch in your age,

(Laughs) I can't believe this is our first date.
I know.. How about dessert?
I suppose I have to get a piece of cake..
Why?
Today's my birthday.
What? Today? Really?
Yeah.
Jerry's apartment]

So, she went out with you on a first date.. and it was

Yeah. And she picked the day!

No, she's great! She's.. attractive, she's fun..

She's not Lincoln.

Nope!
is beating the bushes-

to basically give this money away-

to virtually anyone, as long as they're not you?

Susan Ross Foundation conference room]

(Disappointed) A frog?
Well, I.. I..

(Annoyed) Yeah, yeah. We'll, uh, let you know.

(Smiling gloatingly) You like that, don't you?
so, uh, Steven.. I see you're president of the chess club.
State champs.
Who's your favorite chess player?
(Hesitating, he mumbles) Nastercoff?

Right. (Mumbles) Nastercoff.. What country is he from,

(Sighs) I don't know.. I made it up. (Gets up to leave)

(Gets up, stopping him) Woah, woah, woah! What are you

              (They both sit back down)
I've been telling people that I'd like to be an architect..
Jerry's apartment]

Wow. That's great! When it comes out, I'll have to get someone 
              to ghost read it.
Hey.
Hey.
Hey!

Alright, so there I am at Lorenzo's - loading up my slice

              a pizza) and what-not.. mmm,

The Van Buren Boys? There's a street gang named after President

Oh yeah, and they're just as mean as he was! So, I make

What? What happened?

Because I'm still holding the garlic shaker.. Yeah.. like

Well, what does that mean?

That's their secret sign! See, Van Buren, he was teh eighth

Outside a coffee shop]

(Sees a pay phone) Oh, Jerry, can you hold on a sec? I just

Ellen.

Hey! You guys, I want you to meet Jerry. (Gestures tward

Ohh, we've heard a lot about you! (Confidentially) It

Yeah, you don't even know how much she needs this.
(Sympathetically) She coming of a bad break-up?
(Casually) No.
See ya!
Any messages?
Yeah, no one called.
Coffee shop]

They act like it was some act of charity. Just going out

So, she's the loser of the group. Every group has someone

There is no way Ellen is the loser of that group.
Are you looking deep down at the real person underneath?
No, I'm being as superficial as I possibly can!

(Changing subject) Hey, I htink I may have found someone

Yeah?

I'm interviewing all these annoying little overachievers..

Is he smart?
Hey! Just like you pretend to be.

Yes. With a little guidance, Steven Koren is going to be

I had a dream last night that a hamburger was eating me!
J. Peterman's apartment]

Mister Peterman, thanks for having me over. Your place

Ohhh.. It's just a place to flop. (Sits in his recliner)

Well, (Clears throat) what part of your life (hits the

Oh, Elaine, we've covered all of that in the catalogue

Oh.

(Turns on the T.V, and starts flipping through the channels)

Well, Mister Peterman, do you want to, um..
(Still flipping through the channels) 2.. CBS..
get, um, started..

3.. I don't know what that is.. where's my damn preview

well, I'm sure we'll come up with something. What do

You know, a friend of mine almost got beat up at that place

(Interested) You don't say.

Yeah. The only think that saved him is that he accidentally

Well, that's pretty exciting. (Pause) Let's put that

But, that didn't happen to you.
So, we pay off your friend, and it becomes a Peterman.
No, I - I really don't think you can do that.

(Looking at his dying plant) Ohh, damn. I forgot to buy

You know what? Maybe I better talk to my friend.
Coffee shop]
Is that the same outfit you were wearing yesterday?
No, this is brand new. Do you like it?

Actually, yeah. (Pause) Wait a second! Is that the fork

(Laughs) No, Jerry, the waitress game be another one.
I guess that's all right.
Is something wrong, Jerry?

No, absolutely nothing. (They get up to leave) You're fantastic!

Hey.
(Gesturing to Ellen) Kramer, George, this is Ellen.
Susan Ross Foundation conference room]

Ladies and gentlemen, this (Opens the door, Steven is standing

George, the quailifications for this scholarship were suppose

I'm sure we're all aware of the flaws and biases of standardized

These aren't standardized tests - these are his grades.

Besides, Steven Koren has the highest of aspirations. He

Is that right?
Actually, maybe I could set my sights a little bit higher.
(Laughs) Steven, nothing is higher than an architect.

I think I'd really like to be a city planner. (Sits down,

Well, that's a good point.
(Mutters) No, it's not.

Well, isn't an architect just an art school drop-out with

(Irritated) It's called a T-square.

You know, the stupidest guy in my fraternity became an architect

Thank you.
Susan would be proud of what you're doing.
Thank you.

(Laughs) Kramer, my friend, that is one ripping good

You know, if you like that one, I got more.. what are you

(Interrupting) How much would you take for the whole

My whole lot?
Name your price, man!
(Thinks) 1500 dollars.
I'll give you half that.
(Excited) Done!

Kramer, my friend, (Gestures to Elaine) consider Elaine

Okay.. (To Elaine) Well, I, Uh.. I like to work in the

Well, I'm on the phone with Bob, and I realize right then

What happened to Bob Saccamano?

Well, nothing. His part of the story is done. (Elaine covers

Elaine, are you listening?! I didn't even get there! (Pauses)

Alright, I think I got enough for one day.
Yeah, yeah, chew on that.

Oh, thanks. I've got plans.

Cafe]

(Sourly) I'll make a note of it.
Hey, Kramer,
Yeah?
Ramirez has never heard your pants story.

Yeah.

(Pleading) I was all dirty!
It ever happened! Understand?

(To crowd) Hey, hey, hey! All right! Yeah, uh, yeah.. well..

(Frantic) Kramer, Kramer! I got big trouble with the -

Hey, now, they're tough cookies.

Yeah, and I - I heard you got on their good side. Now,

Uh.. ah, (Looks over at Elaine, and realizes he can't tell

              don't have any stories, if that's

(Frantic) Kramer, do you know what those guys are gonna

Yeah, well, uh.. you know uh, you didn't hear from me,

You mean, like, a former member?
Jerry's apartment]

These Kramer stories are unusable! (Thumbs through them)

Is my toaster oven on there?
How am I ever gonna turn this into a book?
Well, just shape them - change them. You're a writer.
Yes! I'm a writer.
Make them interesting.
Interesting! Of course! People love interesting writing!
Well, I gotta go to the airport. I'm picking up my parents.
What? Wheren't they just here?

Yeah. I'm flying them in to meet Ellen. I don't know where

Maybe we could all have dinner later?

I don't think so. I'm gonna try to get them to fly right

Oh, hey! Hey, have I told you about my bunions? Oh, you're

Kramer, this is awful! We don't want to hear about this!
Damn!
What?

Oh, I bought a bunch of bunion stories from Newman - but 
              they all stink!
How much did you pay for them?

Eight bucks! I think I got ripped off! (Leaves, yelling 
              out "Newman!")
Peterman's office]
Oh, what didn't you like about the first chapter?

Oh, no, no! That's where it gets interesting! Don't you 
              see? The - the train is bearing down on you, you - you dive into 
              a side tunnel - and you run into a

It just seems so cliched, and obvious. It's not interesting

Yeah.. yeah. I know. Um.. how about if, instead of.. diving

              in some mud, and.. ruin your

(Intrigued) The very pants I was returning. That's perfect

I have a Cosmo Kramer on line 4.
(Picks up the phone) Peterman, here.
Mister Peterson, you gotta sell me my stories back!
You want to know something? I no longer need them!

No, no. Mister Peterman, why don't we keep them - as a,

Nonsense! (To Kramer) I have Benes' woderfully imaginative

Yippie-yi-yay!

(Hangs up) There you are, Elaine. Go forth, and create. 
              (Elaine gets up to leave) And, by the way, when you get to that 
              chapter about my romantic
NYC Street]
Hey, Van B. Boys.
So, Mister Costanza, did you get my scholarship back?

Now, fellas, fellas.. easy. You wouldn't want to beat up 
              on one of your own.
Is that right? Then why don't you flash us the sign?

Right.. the sign. (Hesitates, then makes a series of stupid 
              gestures)
That's not the sign.
(Defensively loud) It was when I was banging!

All right, if you really are one of us.. let's see you 
              take the wallet off the next guy who walks by.
Love to! (Cracks his knuckles, then winces under the pain)
Coffee shop]
And after college, I got my masters at the Sorbonne.
Sorbonne? Oh, hey. (To Helen) That's in Paris.

(Looks at her watch) Oh, Jerry, you're parking meter's about 
              to expire. Don't get up, I've got change. (Leaves with her purse)
(To his parents) So? What do you think?
Jerry, she's fantastic.
I knew it! I'm not crazy.
She's so sweet, and she's got some body on her!
And smart! Like a computer!

And so much personality! But, it doesn't matter what we 
              think. Do you like her?

(After seeing how much his parents like her) Now, I'm not 
              so sure.

Well, she's 10 times better than that awful Amber girl that 
              you were with.

Ill 
              see you in hell Costanza.

At Jerrys 
              apartment)

              bye.

Hallway

Hey.

Trouble 
              down at the plant?

Its 
              a tank of oil. Darren and I are finally going to test out my bladder 
              system.

You have 
              to drink that whole thing?

No. No. 
              No. Its for oil tankers. All I need to do is fill some sort

I understand 
              (not really understanding, lol).

Would 
              a giant rubber ball work?
Conceivably.

Well, 
              Play Now has all kinds of different rubber balls. Why dont 
              we test your bladder system at my office?

Youre 
              not

Oh, yes

              dirtier than a giant ball of oil.

At Monks 
              Cafe)

Hey, you 
              want to split a root beer (I think thats what he says)?

I dont 
              think so David, were through.

OhThats 
              a nice sweater (Elaine smiles).

At Elaines 
              house  the two are in bed)

Whew that 
              was a dozy.

At Jerrys 
              apartment)
Go again?
Book it.

(again 
              from bathroom) Witness.

At Elaines 
              apartment)

David 
              I know this hurts, but its the way it has to be (Puddy is 
              giving her a look like hes going to still get some).

At Jerrys 
              apartment)

Ha ha ha. 
              Ha ha ha ha.

Jerry 
              and Elaine at the movies)

Im 
              going to get some popcorn.

At Jerrys 
              apartment)

So, how 
              did it end?

They got 
              away.
uh.

At Elaines 
              apartment)

Listen 
              David, Ive got to run. Can you lend me fifty bucks?

At Play 
              Now)
Hey.

Did you 
              bring the video camera?

Yeah, I 
              put a six hour tape in. That should cover the experiment, the arrest,

Oh, you 
              might want to stick around Jerry. Mr. Thomassoulo picked the wrong

You gave 
              up the voice?

Yeah, I

No. No
Darren?

Sorry

Uh, bathroom.

Hey, use

I thought

I uh, 
              took care of that.

Wow! Zanadu 
              . No wonder youre putting in so many hours. (looks at urinal)

I insist. 
              Ill fix us a drink. (phone rings  who would that be?) 
              I got it.

Whew. 
              You know Darren, if you would have told me twenty-five years ago

              energy problems, I wouldve said youre crazy Now 
              lets push this giant ball of oil out the window.

So, check 
              out my view.

Wow! Hey, 
              theres Clare. I better go down.

Hey, theres 
              Kramer & Darren.

Theres 
              the giant ball of oil. Clares right underneath that thing.

I dont 
              believe this. I am not looking up if youre going to 
              do that voice.

Bombs 
              away (Uh oh).

This is 
              going to be a shame.
Hello.

Well, 
              that didnt work. Hey, how about thisketchup and mustard

Oh that 
              sounds interesting sir.
Yeah.

At Monks 
              Caf)

Clare won 
              her lawsuit against Play Now. Gee, Play Now is filing for bankruptcy. 
              I guess youre not going in anymore.
Yeah.

So theyre 
              not paying you your
No.

So youre 
              pretty much
Yeah.

What ever 
              happened to Darren?

Darren 
              is going away for a long long time.

So Clare 
              sure looked real funny covered in oil like that (doing the 
              voice) Hello-o-o-o I got beamed with a giant ball of oil

(doing 
              the voice) Im slippery as an eel

(doing 
              the voice) La la la.

Im

At Elaines

      Transcribed by
line: Juha Auvinen
October 16, 1997

Jerry Seinfeld....................... Jerry Seinfeld 
        Jason Alexander.................. George Costanza 
        Julia Louis-Dreyfus.............. Elaine Benes 
        Michael Richards................. Cosmo Kramer

Kellie Vaymire [ Vivian ] 
        Audrey Kissel [ Tara ] 
        Colton James [ Jimmy ] 
        Gene Dynarsky [ Izzy Jr. ] 
        Yvonne Farrow [ Employee ] 
        Lloyd Bridges [ Izzy Mandelbaum ]
Are you sure you can't stay longer?
No, we just came for the funeral. `
Poor Marvin Kessler, he went too early.
He was 96 years old.
That had nothing to do with it, the man was out of shape.

That's why we joined a program. We walk once around the block 
        three times a week.
And every morning I eat a plum.
Well, what ever you do, you're wearing me out.
What about you?
Yeah, looks like you're getting a little spare tire there, tiger.
Really?
Hey, Seinfelds!
Hey, Mr. Kramer!
How long are you staying?
We just came down for a funeral.

Oh yeah, yeah I heard, Marvin Kessler. Boy, that makes you think. 
        If he could go...
See you downstairs with the car.
Are you sure you don't need a hand with that?
No no, the luggage is on the program. I got a brick in here.
Did you give blood?

No, not giving. hoarding. I'm storing it in to a blood bank. 
        Just in case.
In case of what?

Jerry, I know myself. If I'm out on the street and it's starts 
        to go down, I don't back off until it's finished.
Are we finished?
Done.
Elaine, I'm so glad you came out.
Yeah...
You haven't seen Jimmy for years.

I know, I'm glad I got to see him before he hit puberty and got, 
        you know all lurchy and awkward.
Actually, I'm gonna need someone to look after him tomorrow evening.
Tomorrow evening, sure.
Do you know anyone responsible?
Do I know anyone??
Well, if you think of anybody, give me a call.
What are you doing?
Incense, for the mood.

Oh yes, by no means, the mood. Let me know if there's anything 
        I can do to lend support to the mood.
Um, cream soda?
Vanilla.
Can you believe that, Vivian doesn't think I'm responsible?
I couldn't raise a kid? Come on, I love bossing people around.
What happened, I thought you were with Tara tonight?

I was, I had to leave. She lit some vanilla incenses. The smell 
        drove me nuts, all I could think about was food, I had to get out of there. 
        We need some pudding here! Pudding!
You just left? What did you tell her?

I told I had a bus transfer that was only good just for another 
        hour.
What?
I don't know, I was starving Jerry!
Oh, pudding! You want some?
Hey, you guys think I'm getting a little...chunky?

What are you kidding? We look great! You know what this pudding 
        needs? The skin on the top, you know like your mother used to make it 
        on the stove.
Elaine, what do you think?
I think you're getting a little pudding under the skin yourself.

My service rates went up? You banks are all the same with your 
        hidden fees and your service charges. Well, maybe I'll just take my blood 
        elsewhere, yeah.
Well, we can transfer to another bank for you.

Oh, no no no...no more banks. I'm keeping my blood in my freezer 
        with...my money!
So eh, what do you say?
I guess we could use some food in our lovemaking.

Ok, we got your...got your strawberries, your chocolate sauce, 
        your pastrami on rye with mustard, your honey...
Wait wait wait, pastrami on rye with mustard?

Oh yeah yeah, don't you know they used pastrami in that movie 
        9 weeks? Remember the pastrami scene?
No.
Well, maybe it was Ghostbusters? Where ever it was, it worked!
Didn't go for it, huh?
No.

So, she didn't appreciate the erotic qualities of the salted cured 
        meats?

She tolerated the strawberries and the chocolate sauce, but eh, 
        it's not a meal, you know? Food and sex, those are my two passions. It's 
        only natural to combine them.

Natural? Sex is about love between a man and a woman, not a man 
        and a sandwich.
Jerry, I'm not suggesting getting rid of the girl. She's integral.

Maybe instead of trying to satisfy two of your needs, how about 
        satisfying one of somebody else's.

Hey, speaking of which, I found a great way to separate the skin 
        from the top of the pudding without leaving any around the edges; Exacto 
        knife.

I told you George, no more pudding. I'm starting a purification 
        program. Keep all that kind of food away from me.

Well, I guess these would be out of the question. [pulls out 
        two pudding skins in plastic bags.]
What the hell is that?
Pudding skin singles.
Hey buddy, I'm borrowing all your Tupperware.
Oh, why?
I closed down my account at the blood bank.
What, it...it's here in the building?
Right across the hall. What, you wanna go see?

No I don't! In fact, if even one corpuscles of that blood should 
        find it's way across that hall I will freak out on you Kramer! Freak out.
You know, for a fat guy you're not very jolly.
Hey, working out?
You know it and I ditched all my junk food.
What the heck is going on here?
Sorry buddy, clean house. It's all health food.
Well, I may have to take it, but I don't have to like it.

Vivian left me a message. I guess a certain someone changed her 
        mind about whether someone was responsible enough to watch certain other 
        someone.
Is this about me?
No.
Oh, then I lost interest.

Vivian, hi it's Elaine. Yeah, I'm over at Jerry's, I got your 
        message...What? Yeah, he's right here, hold on...[hands the phone to Kramer.]

For me? Go...Yeah, what tonight? Yeah, I'll be there...Yeah later. 
        [puts the phone down] Well, somebody's baby-sitting.
You? I'm more responsible than you are!

Don't be ridiculous. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go to 
        fill my freezer with my own blood.
Oh, Tara!
Hello, Vivian! Oh, this is a nice screen.
Kramer...
Don't take my money!

It is me, you idiot. Hi, all right you've got to get out of here, 
        I'm gonna baby-sit the hell out of that kid.
No, I'm the baby-sitter.
No no no, you're out, I'm in. Now, hit the road.
Elaine? What are you doing here?

Kramer is actually sleeping one off, so I thought that I'd help 
        out...[Kramer moans from the bushes] what's that, some raccoon or something...[hits 
        Kramer with a broom.]

Well, I guess this would be all right. Jimmy, you remember Elaine? 
        She's gonna watch you tonight.

Hi Jimmy. [Jimmy kicks Elaine to the shin.] Ouch! [The screen 
        door hits her in the head.]

Hey, what are you doing here? I thought you were baby-sitting 
        at Vivian's.
There was an incident.

Oh no, where's the blood? [opens the fridge] It's in here isn't 
        it?
Would you stop it.
What is this?
It's Jell-O.
What about this? This is blood isn't it?!
This is tomato juice, look...[drinks from the bottle.]
Ooh, you're sick! You're sick!!

Will you calm down. I took all my blood down to Newman's. He 
        let me put it in his meat freezer.
Hey, what's going on? Who made pudding?

This hallway smells like potatoes.

Alright, fine fine, I'll do it.
Oh mama.

I enjoy the challenge of medicine. Naturally you have no idea what

No.
Cause I hit a whopper last week!
Here you go, airbrushed in to sand and sky.

I am aware!

Hmm, the world's best pizza cutter. 76 bucks, how often

The cat.
He took out Kruger?

This slicer is indomitable.

Flowers?
Yeah, you gotta do it classy [wipes his mouth to his sweater.]
So, you've done this?

        [Jerry is on the revenge date with Sara.]

Drawer.

Bagels?

When George was growing up..
(Interrupting) No!
His father..
